fields.question_text: A knot or sharp radius bend of a towline reduces rope strength by:
fields.option_d: no appreciable reduction in strength
fields.explanation: "A knot in the towline reduces its strength by up to 50 percent, and causes a high spot in the rope that is more susceptible to wear. Pay particular attention to the ring area to which the glider attaches because this is also a high-wear area." Glider Flying Handbook (2013), page 5-5

fields.question_text: The primary function of the rudder is to:
fields.option_a: turn the glider
fields.option_b: counteract aileron drag
fields.option_c: assist in recovery from stalls and spins
fields.option_d: provide extra propulsion at the beginning of the aerotow
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook, page 3-12

When you roll into a turn, the aileron on the inside of the turn is raised and the aileron on the outside of the turn is lowered. The lowered aileron on the outside increases the angle of attack and produces more lift for that wing. Since induced drag is a by-product of lift, the outside wing also produces more drag than the inside wing. This causes a yawing tendency toward the outside of the turn called adverse yaw. Coordinated use of rudder and aileron corrects for adverse yaw and aileron drag.

fields.question_text: Unless supplemental oxygen is used, some deterioration of physical and mental performance occurs after prolonged flight at
fields.explanation:
AIM 8-1-2 Hypoxia

2. Although a deterioration in night vision occurs at a cabin pressure altitude as low as 5,000 feet, other significant effects of altitude hypoxia usually do not occur in the normal healthy pilot below 12,000 feet. From 12,000 to 15,000 feet of altitude, judgment, memory, alertness, coordination and ability to make calculations are impaired, and headache, drowsiness, dizziness and either a sense of well-being (euphoria) or belligerence occur. The effects appear following increasingly shorter periods of exposure to increasing altitude. In fact, pilot performance can seriously deteriorate within 15 minutes at 15,000 feet.

Glider Flying Handbook, page 10-12

At around 20,000 feet MSL pilots might have only 10 minutes of “useful consciousness.” By 30,000 feet MSL, the timeframe for “useful consciousness” decreases to one minute or less.

fields.question_text: The greatest danger when flying at high altitudes is a condition known as
fields.option_a: dehydration
fields.option_b: asphyxiation
fields.option_c: hyperventilation
fields.option_d: hypoxia
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook, page 1-10

High-altitude flying, which glider pilots encounter when mountain wave soaring or thermal soaring at high elevations, can place you in danger of becoming hypoxic. Oxygen starvation causes the brain and other vital organs to become impaired.

fields.question_text: Rapid breathing, or hyperventilation, results from an inadequate supply of:
fields.option_a: carbon dioxide
fields.option_b: carbon monoxide
fields.option_c: oxygen
fields.option_d: nitrogen
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook, page 1-12

Hyperventilation occurs when you are experiencing emotional stress, fright, or pain, and your breathing rate and depth increase although the carbon dioxide is already at a reduced level in the blood. The result is an excessive loss of carbon dioxide from your body, which can lead to unconsciousness due to the respiratory system’s overriding mechanism to regain control of breathing.

fields.question_text: The safest course of action for the pilot in command who is suffering from motion sickness is to:
fields.option_a: drink some water
fields.option_b: close the air vents
fields.option_c: take a dramamine tablet
fields.option_d: land the glider, when practicable
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook, page 1-14

It is important to remember that experiencing airsickness is no reflection on your ability as a pilot. Let your flight instructor know if you are prone to motion sickness since there are techniques that can be used to overcome this problem. For example, you may want to avoid lessons in turbulent conditions until you are more comfortable in the glider, or start with shorter flights and graduate to longer instruction periods. If you experience symptoms of motion sickness during a lesson, you can alleviate some of the discomfort by opening fresh air vents or by focusing on objects outside the glider. Although medication like Dramamine can prevent airsickness in passengers, it is not recommended while you are flying since it can cause drowsiness.

Although opening air vents is suitable for more minor cases of motion sickness, answer D is the best choice for solo flight.

fields.question_text: If the towplane should lose power during the takeoff roll, what action should be taken by the sailplane pilot?
fields.option_a: an immediate release and turn to the left
fields.option_b: an immediate release and straight ahead stop, avoiding the towplane to the left, if necessary
fields.option_c: an immediate release and turn to the right
fields.option_d: an immediate release and straight ahead stop, avoiding the towplane to the right, if necessary
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook pages 7-4 and 7-5

Situation 1. If the towrope breaks or is inadvertently released prior to the towplane’s liftoff, the standard procedure is for the towplane to continue the takeoff and clear the runway, or abort the takeoff and remain on the left side of the runway. If the towplane loses power during the takeoff, the towpilot should maneuver the towplane to the left side of the runway. If the glider is still on the runway, the glider pilot should pull the release, decelerate using the wheel brake, and be prepared to maneuver to the right side of the runway.

fields.question_text: When a side slip is performed during a crosswind landing, the ground track should be:
fields.option_a: sideways, in the direction of the lowered wing
fields.option_b: in the opposite direction of the crosswind
fields.option_c: a gentle curve towards the runway centerline
fields.option_d: straight and parallel to the runway and the sailplane's longitudinal axis
fields.explanation: The point of the side slip is to counteract any crosswind, while maintaining the runway's extended centerline.  The difference between a side slip and crabbing is that the side slip counteracts the crosswind while maintaining the aircraft's longitudinal axis along the ground track.  Crabbing is when the aircraft's nose is pointed upwind to maintain ground track.

fields.question_text: If too much altitude is lost on the base leg to permit a safe turn to final, the best course of action is to:
fields.option_a: continue the pattern and land short
fields.option_b: land out of the base leg, find the best available spot
fields.option_c: raise the nose to conserve altitude
fields.option_d: close the speedbrakes/spoilers to stretch the glide
fields.explanation: This is one of those circumstances where the best answer really is "it depends", and none of these options are very savory. Remember, the scenario is that the glider has gotten too low on base leg to permit a safe turn to final.  If this is the case, closing the speed brakes isn't going to make the turn to final any safer.  Raising the nose only increases the chance of a stall, and doesn't increase the chance of making it to the runway.  Continuing the pattern to land short isn't going to be an option, because you're already too low to turn to final.  None of these options are very good, and it's better not to get into this situation in the first place.  At Front Royal, when landing on runway 28, continuing on the base leg is probably the "least terrible" course of action.

fields.question_text: Directional control is maintained after a crosswind touchdown by applying
fields.option_a: aileron into the wind
fields.option_b: aileron away from the wind
fields.option_c: rudder into the wind
fields.option_d: whatever is necessary to track the centerline - could be rudder away from the wind to control weather-vaning, could be aileron into the wind to hold wings level, could be aileron away from the wind to deliberately lower the downwind wing to the runway to keep the upwind wing above runway lights if unable to track the centerline
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook , page 7-36 through 7-38

The GFH references focus on final approach and the flare.  AFTER touchdown in a crosswind, which is the question, use whatever controls are necessary.  Aileron into the wind may be needed to keep a crosswind from blowing the upwind wing up, while attempting to maintain wings level.  Rudder away from the wind may be required to keep the glider from weather-vaning into the wind. If the glider is still weather-vaning, a deliberate but gentle aileron input away from the wind to fly the downwind wing to the runway may help straighten the glider out and keep the upwind wing above runway edge lights if departing the centerline (while applying brakes).

fields.question_text: The pilot makes initial contact with a thermal and turns to the right. Between 90 degrees and 180 degrees of rotation from the initial contact, the variometer drops from 3 knots lift to 0 knots. This decrease in lift indicates:
fields.option_a: a turn in the wrong direction
fields.option_b: a late turn
fields.option_c: an early turn
fields.option_d: a proper turn
fields.explanation: GFH, page 10-6. "Soaring pilots’ opinions differ regarding how long to wait after encountering lift and before rolling into the thermal. Some pilots advocate flying straight until the lift has peaked. Then, they start turning, hopefully back into stronger lift. It is imperative not to wait too long after the first indication that the thermal is decreasing for this maneuver. Other pilots favor rolling into the thermal before lift peaks, thus avoiding the possibility of losing the thermal by waiting too long. Turning into the lift too quickly will cause the glider to fly back out into sink. There is no one right way; the choice depends on personal preference and the conditions on a given day. Timing is everything and practice is key."

fields.question_text: When searching for a thermal the recommended speed to maintain is

fields.question_text: The best airspeed to use while thermalling is
fields.option_a: manuevering speed
fields.option_b: Best L/D speed
fields.option_c: minimum control speed
fields.option_d: minimum sink speed, considering the angle of bank being used for the turn to stay in the thermal
fields.explanation: The best airspeed to use while thermalling is a compromise between minimizing turn radius and minimizing sink rate.  See Glider Flying Handbook pages 3-12 and 10-6 through 10-11.  Minimum sink speed at 40 degrees of bank (common in a thermal) is faster than minimum sink speed in level flight in calm air.  Maneuvering speed would be way too fast.  Best L/D speed is normally too fast.  Minimum control speed is too slow, even if thermalling straight and level in a cloud street.

fields.question_text: The crest of mountain waves may be marked by
fields.option_a: cumulus clouds
fields.option_b: cirrus clouds
fields.option_c: lenticular clouds
fields.option_d: rotor clouds

fields.question_text: when flying near mountain wave, the turbulent area beneath the wave may be marked by
fields.option_a: cumulus clouds
fields.option_b: cirrus clouds
fields.option_c: lenticular clouds
fields.option_d: rotor clouds
fields.explanation:
Cumulus clouds are cauliflower-shaped.  They are caused by lifting from below.  They are not usually associated with wave activity. 

Cirrus clouds (actually cirro-stratus clouds) are generally indications of a warm frontal passage that is approaching in the next few days. 

Lenticular clouds are the smooth, almond shaped clouds that are located in the smooth part of the wave lift.  Their presence does not indicate turbulence where the lenticular clouds are. 

Rotor clouds are the gnarly clouds that reside under the lenticular clouds.  They are the ones that indicate turbulence.

fields.question_text: No pilot may operate a glider unless it has which of the following required documents onboard:
fields.option_a: Airworthiness Certificate, Registration Certificate, Aircraft Logbooks
fields.option_b: Airworthiness Certificate, Registration Certificate, OperatingLimits
fields.option_c: Registration Certificate, Weight & Balance, Bill of Sale
fields.option_d: Airworthiness Certificate, Registration, Operating Limitations, Weight & Balance
fields.explanation:
If you got this wrong, you probably should learn the AR[R]OW mnemonic. 

A.R.O.W.

Aviation mnemonic to remind you of the required documents to make an aircraft airworthy. These documents are checked as part of any pre-flight inspection.

Without these documents the airplane can be brand new and in perfect shape but still be unairworthy. The required documents are:

Airworthiness Certificate.
Registration.
Operating limitations.
Weight and Balance


Airworthiness Certificate:
Each aircraft is issued an airtworthiness certificate as it leaves the factory. This certificate certifies that the airplane meets the design requirements and is safe to operate.

Registration:
Just like the registration in your car. It includes things like Owner's name, registration number, Owner's address, and aircraft serial number.

Operating limitations:
Most people think this means having the aircraft's Pilot Operating Handbook (POH). That is usually true however there is another requirement and that is placards. Some placards are required by Airworthiness Directive (AD) or by the aircraft's type certificate. These placards are considered part of the operating limitations.

Weight and Balance:
A current weight and balance sheet is required to be kept in the aircraft. Also, if the aircraft's weight and balance has a special condition (such as the aircraft is easily loaded out of aft C.G. under normal loading conditions) a loading chart must be kept with the weight and balance.

If you happen to be flying internationally today you will need to add another "R" document and that is a current FCC Radio Station License.

fields.question_text: Under which case would it NOT be mandatory that a glider pilot immediately release from tow:
fields.option_a: The tow plane rocks its wings
fields.option_b: The tow plane and glider experience severe turbulence
fields.option_c: The tow plane cannot be seen from the glider cockpit
fields.option_d: The tow pilot ejects from the tow plane
fields.explanation:
If the towplane rocks its wings, that is the signal to immediately release. 

If the towplane can not be seen from the glider cockpit, formation flight can no longer be maintained, and the glider must release.

If the tow pilot ejects from the tow plane, formation flight can no longer be maintained, and the glider must release.

Severe turbulence is not a mandatory situation where the glider must release, or there would never be any good wave flights out of Petersburg.

fields.question_text: While under tow at a "comfortable" altitude, all of a sudden the tow plane starts a rapid descent to the left.  What should you do?

There probably isn't going to be enough time to turn the glider into the opposite direction before releasing, so just pull the release and continue the flight from there.

fields.question_text: Shortly after takeoff the tow pilot rapidly fans the rudder of the towplane.  The glider pilot should:

fields.option_b: release immediately
fields.option_c: position the glider to a lower tow position
fields.option_d: Close your canopy - it may be open
fields.explanation:
This signal is not referenced in the Glider Flying Handbook (2003).

The signal is used to indicate that "Something is wrong with the glider"  In this case, either A or D could be considered correct answers.  However, at low altitude "shortly after takeoff" opened spoilers are more critical to the safe continuation of flight than an open canopy.  Check the spoilers first!  Don't release unless you are in a good position to release, and don't confuse the signals of "Release immediately!" (rocking the wings) with "Something is wrong with the glider" (rapid fanning of the rudder).

fields.question_text: CFR 91.126 provides that '...When approaching to land at an airport without an operating control tower in a Class G airspace area' ... each pilot of an airplane must make all turns to the left unless the airport displays approved light signals or visual markings indicating that turns must be made to the right..' At FRR, the established procedures require power planes to use standard left traffic on both runways but glider traffic use right traffic. Why?

fields.option_b: Because the airport directory's remarks section defines glider, helicopter, and gyroplane traffic as right-hand
fields.option_c: Because the airport's management asks us to

  • Airport management indeed asks that gliders fly a right-hand pattern, but this request carries no weight compared to the airport facility directory listing.
  • It is important to maintain separation from power traffic, but there are airports where separation by different pattern shapes is impossible, such as at New Market or Luray, where the patterns are defined as the same for all categories of air traffic.

fields.question_text: On a solo training flight in the local area, what is the first thing you should do safely free of the tow plane?
fields.option_a: check for traffic
fields.option_b: look for potential sources of lift
fields.option_c: locate the airport
fields.option_d: trim for best L/D speed
fields.explanation:
This question is tricky, and a case could be made for each one of the possible answers. What we really need here is an answer that says "it depends."

"Check for traffic" in our opinion, you should have checked for traffic before releasing -- but certainly checking for traffic is important.  Trimming for best L/D airspeed should only be done if you are heading to a particular location.  If you have released in a thermal, it would not be appropriate to trim for best L/D.  Looking for potential lift is important, but finding the airport is far more critical -- If you are not sure where the airport is, look to the towplane and see where he's going!  Getting lost on a solo flight is no fun.

fields.option_b: downhill - provides softer touch-down

Glider Flying Handbook , page 8-9

Even a slight downhill grade during landing flare allows the glider to float prior to touchdown, which may reuslt in collision with objects on the far end of the selected field"

fields.question_text: Proper "scanning" involves:
fields.option_a: Scanning the horizon for anything that moves
fields.option_b: Focusing on a series of distant objects to discern moving objects in peripheral vision
fields.option_c: Focusing on distant ground objects to get your eyes adjusted
fields.option_d: Concentrating on objects in your intended flight path
fields.explanation:
See AIM 8-1-6.  That section in the AIM recommends finding a small portion of the sky, studying it for small objects, and moving on to the next section of sky.  The use of peripheral vision is not useful because aircraft on a collision course will not have any relative motion, and peripheral vision only detects objects with relative motion. 

Focusing on distant objects helps guard against 'empty field myopia', referenced in AIM 8-1-6. 

Concentrating on objects in your intended flight path is no good because a mid-air collision is also possible from the side, as well as from the front. 

Also see AC 90-48C , Collision Avoidance.

fields.question_text: A glider loaded so that the cg is too far aft will:
fields.option_a: Be predisposed to fly too fast, and may exceed Vne
fields.option_b: Be difficult to control
fields.option_c: Have a high sink rate
fields.option_d: Be very unlikely to stall or spin
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook , page 5-11 

"If the glider is loaded so the CG location is behind the aft limit, handling is compromised. The glider is said to be tail-heavy. Tail heaviness can make pitch control of the glider difficult or even impossible.

When the glider is tail-heavy recovering from a stall may be difficult or impossible. When the stall occurs, the tail-heavy loading tends to make the glider nose continue to pitch upward, increasing angle of attack and complicating stall recovery. In extreme cases, recovery from stall or spin may be difficult or even impossible. "

fields.question_text: "Speed to fly" means the correct speed to fly:
fields.option_a: In the pattern, but not before the final approach speed
fields.option_b: To minimize the sink rate of the glider while flying through lift and sink
fields.option_c: In turbulence; the maximum allowable speed while still preventing damage to the aircraft
fields.option_d: in general; covering the most ground with minimum loss of altitude
fields.explanation: Speed to fly is not the pattern speed, even though the normal pattern speed we fly is very close to the maximum L/D speed.  It is also not the speed we use to minimize the sink rate -- that's the 'minimum sink speed'.  Speed to fly is not to be confused with V<sub>NO</sub>, the maximum structural crusing speed -- so it has nothing to do with turbulence.  Speed to fly is the speed that for a given headwind or tailwind, a given lift or sink, maximizes the glide ratio of the glider with reference to the ground.

fields.question_text: What is the first thing to do if the canopy starts opening in flight?
fields.option_a: don't stop "aviating"
fields.option_b: above all else, reach for the flapping canopy
fields.option_c: step on the rudder opposite the canopy hinge
fields.option_d: inform Skyline base of what has happened
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook page 8-11  

If the canopy opens while on aerotow, it is vital to maintain a normal flying attitude to avoid jeopardizing the safety of the glider occupants and the safety of the towplane pilot. Only when the glider pilot is certain that glider control can be maintained should any attention be devoted to trying to close the canopy. If flying a two-seat glider with a companion aboard, concentrate on lying the glider while the other person attempts to close and lock the canopy. If the canopy cannot be closed, the glider may still be controllable. Drag will be higher than normal, so when flying the approach it is best to plan a steeper-than-normal descent path. The best prevention against unexpected opening of the canopy is proper use of the pre-takeoff checklist.

fields.question_text: The Linden VOR is located 4.4 NM SSE of FRR. It is a common approach fix for traffic inbound to lAD, and is also a major Victor Airway intersection.

fields.option_c: This is not a problem because all traffic inbound to IAD is under ATC radar surveillance
fields.option_d: This is not a problem because gliders have the right-of-way over powered aircraft
fields.explanation:

  • Just because inbound aircraft are under ATC surveillance does not mean that the ATC is aware of your presence, and it does not mean that the ATC will direct inbound traffic away from your glider in this area.  (Especially if your aircraft is not transponder-equipped)
  • Gliders do not have right-of-way over powered aircraft in all conditions, only when on converging and non-head-on courses (See §91.113)
The best answer for these is 'exercise extreme caution', but it might be even safer to avoid medium to high altitude flights in this area all-together.

fields.question_text: On takeoff on RW 28 on a very cold day with winds of 15kts out of the southwest, the towplane suffers a catastrophic engine failure at an altitude of about 50ft. Without performing the standard signal to you (rocking the wings), the tow pilot releases the towline and dives toward the short grass overrun to RW 28. You are approximately 900ft east of threshold to RW 10. You should:

fields.option_b: Clear the release, pull full spoilers, and land in the area ahead, avoiding the towplane, wherever he is
fields.option_c: Glide to the emergency field on the left, clearing the trees and looking for power lines.
fields.option_d: Execute a 180 deg turn to the left, pull full spoilers, and land downwind on the takeoff runway.
fields.explanation:
Glider Flying Handbook , page 7-5 (in this situation) the glider has insufficient runway directly ahead and has insufficient altitude to make a safe turn, the best course of action is to land the glider straight ahead. After touchdown, use wheel brake as necessary to slow and stop as conditions permit. 

Since the glider still has the rope attached, clearing the release when possible is highly advisable.  You don't want the situation to get worse by getting the nose pulled down by an entangled rope while landing.
