fields.option_c: He is asking you to check that the aircraft is untied
fields.option_d: He is announcing that he has completed her pre-start check list

fields.question_text: At KFRR gliders may land:
fields.option_a: Anywhere in an emergency
fields.option_b: On the runway if available
fields.option_c: On the grass if the runway is not available, or on the taxiway if the grass is not available
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation: If there is an issue of pilot and aircraft safety, the glider may be landed anywhere on airport property. However, this does not give license to routinely land on the grass strip adjacent to the published runway, or on the taxiway.  Normal landings should take place on the paved runway.

fields.question_text: Which of the following statements about pushing a glider is NOT correct?
fields.option_a: Gliders at Skyline are typically pushed backwards while on paved surfaces
fields.option_b: Pushing on the trailing edge of a wing or control surface can cause damage
fields.option_c: Pushing backwards in tall grass or across a lip can cause damage to the rudder
fields.option_d: Gliders may only be pushed backwards
fields.explanation: At Skyline we typically push gliders backwards on pavement because it is convenient and safe to push from the nose or leading edge of the wing root and the base of the vertical tail.  Gliders can be damaged by pushing forward on the trailing edge of the wing or any control surface.  Glider rudders can be damaged by pushing backwards in tall grass or across a lip such as the edge of a taxiway.  The best direction to push a glider depends on the type of glider and the situation.

fields.question_text: As you turn onto the downwind leg to land on Runway 28, you see a non-radio equipped airplane already on his base leg and below you.  You should:
fields.option_a: Open spoilers and execute an abbreviated pattern, since gliders have the right-of-way over airplanes.
fields.option_b: Close spoilers, slow to minimum sink speed, and circle until the airplane has cleared the runway..
fields.option_c: Declare an emergency on the CTAF and select the alternate runway on your landing checklist.
fields.option_d: Proceed with caution, announce your position on the CTAF, and be prepared to land on an alternate runway if conflict with the airplane is obvious.
fields.explanation: Many pilots erroneously believe the glider has the right-of-way in this situation; slowing and circling in the pattern increases the liklihood of creating a more dangerous situation; the situation is not sufficiently significant to declare an emergency; glider pilots should always have alternatives when the situation beyond their control changes.

fields.question_text: Never push a glider by:
fields.option_a: The trailing edge of the tail surfaces
fields.option_b: The trailing edge surfaces of the wing
fields.option_c: The canopy
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation:
• No trailing edges should be pushed, they could damage the surface.
  • Pushing on the canopy can cause thousands of dollars of damage

fields.question_text: Use extreme caution opening and closing canopies because:
fields.option_a: They are fragile
fields.option_b: They are expensive
fields.option_c: They are not easy to replace
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation: the obvious choice is D.

fields.question_text: The ASK-21 rear canopy must remain closed at all times unless someone is entering or exiting the rear cockpit because:
fields.option_a: When the canopy is open, it can set the glider on fire
fields.option_b: Wind can easily damage the rear canopy
fields.option_c: It would damage the glider if someone takes off with it open
fields.option_d: The front canopy cannot be latched shut unless the rear canopy is closed
fields.explanation:
It only takes a few moments for the front or rear canopies to start a fire due to the lens effect. We often stress that the rear canopy is the one that can start fires, but there have been melted front cockpits on ASK-21s, as well. 

B is only true for very strong winds, > 30 mph

C is true, but isn't resolved by a closed rear canopy, it's only resolved by a locked rear canopy

D is incorrect because the front canopy can not be latched unless the rear canopy is latched.

fields.question_text: When ground-towing gliders:
fields.option_a: If towing without a tail dolly, use a second person to push down on the nose or pick up the tail when the glider is turning
fields.option_b: Use a second person on the nose or tail to prevent the glider from rolling into the tow vehicle when towing downhill
fields.option_c: Ensure the tow rope is longer than the half the total wingspan, so if the glider pivots the wing will not strike the tow vehicle
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation:
A) We can prevent excessive wear and tear on the glider's tailwheel by picking it up while the glider is turning. It's preferable to pick up the tail at the tail of the aircraft, rather than pushing down on the nose.  Pushing down on the nose makes it possible for a sudden acceleration to trap the crew under the glider, or to get hit by the wing of the glider.   If picking the tail up, make sure to do so from the inside of the horizontal stabilizer, instead of the tips.  In all circumstances, a tail dolly is most preferable for ground operations.

B) When towing downhill, such as towards the approach end of runway 10, it is possible for a glider to accelerate towards the tow vehicle, and you may not be able to slow the glider from the wingtip without turning it

C) If the glider starts to pivot and it is close to the tow vehicle, the wingtip may hit the tow vehicle; holding back one wingtip may make the other wingtip swing forward

D) All of the above are true

fields.question_text: When entering or exiting a glider, you should
fields.option_a: wait for the instructor to get in first
fields.option_b: never step directly on the seat cushion
fields.option_c: use the seat straps to pull on for leverage
fields.option_d: never grab the canopy
fields.explanation:
The canopy is the most fragile and delicate part of the cockpit.  Replacing it is terribly expensive!  Also don't touch the canopy because the fingerprints reduce visibility. 

"never step directly on the seat cushion" is also true, but not as important as "never grab the canopy"

fields.question_text: It is important to announce yourself before pushing a glider onto the runway:
fields.option_a: to be sure that no glider is about to land
fields.option_b: to indicate to the tow plane that you are ready to launch
fields.option_c: because doing so assures that you will not interfere with runway traffic
fields.option_d: to add a level of safety -- although you must also clear the area visually
fields.explanation:
D is correct -- making the radio call only adds to the safety, and still you must look for incoming traffic, even if you made the radio call. 

A is incorrect because an incoming glider may not have a working radio.  If you go out to the active runway without clearing first, at least he will be aware of your position and intentions, and be able to act accordingly, but making the radio call alone does not ensure that there are no gliders about to land.

B is incorrect because there are many circumstances when he is aware you are ready to launch without a radio call. 

C is incorrect because making a call does not mean you are not going to interfere with runway traffic.  An incoming plane on final approach will find your call and rolling out onto the runway as an interference with his final approach.

fields.question_text: FAA regulations require that a tow rope must
fields.option_a: be at least 150 feet long
fields.option_b: must be at least as strong as 80 percent of the minimum flying weight of the glider
fields.option_c: must have the appropriate rings on each end
fields.option_d: may not be stronger than 200 percent of the gross weight of the glider
fields.explanation:
A is incorrect because the regulations don't specify any rope length at all. 

B is incorrect because the regulation doesn't specify the percentage against the minimum flying weight of the glider. 

C is incorrect because the regulations don't specify what kind of connections there must be. However, hooking up the tost ring on the Sprite could be disastrous!

Reference: 91.309 Towing: Gliders and unpowered ultralight vehicles.

fields.question_text: The maneuvering speed is shown on the airspeed indicator of the ASK-21 where
fields.option_a: the top of the green arc
fields.option_b: the top of the yellow arc
fields.option_c: the yellow triangle
fields.option_d: it is not shown on the airspeed indicator
fields.explanation:
As a general rule, the top of the yellow arc is not maneuvering speed, but the normal operating range (VNO). Aircraft certified by the FAA follow this convention. The ASK-21 is a different story. The addage of "do whatever the manual says" applies here.  When the ASK-21 was certified in 1980 in West Germany, the convention of VNO at the of the green arc didn't yet apply. 

Gliders certified in Europe since 2001 all share the convention of VNO at the top of the green arc. 

See FAA-H-8083 page 4-3, which lists the colors on airspeed indicator markings. Maneuvering Speed is listed under "Other airspeed limitations".

fields.question_text: SSC uses a designates the official 'IP' (Initial Point) as the beginning of the glider landing pattern:
fields.option_a: There is no official 'point' designated as IP
fields.option_b: You must learn each different instructor's preference of IP, and use that one when flying with that instructor
fields.option_c: For 28 approach, the bend in the road, for 10 approach, use the pond
fields.option_d: about 700 feet perpendicular to the opposite end of the runway you are landing on.
fields.explanation: To avoid teaching landmarks as specific 'crutches' to landing pattern techniques, SSC's policy is simply to enter - and announce - a more general '45 degree intercept' to the downwind leg. Similarly, students are not taught to turn from downwind to base leg based on a ground marker. In general, we support the TLAR pattern technique.

fields.question_text: If the transponder's battery fails in flight, you must:
fields.option_a: keep the transponder on. The regs require it to be on if equipped.
fields.option_b: turn off the transponder by hitting the circuit breaker switch on the instrument panel
fields.option_c: Turn off the transponder at the control head and transponder master power switch, and after the flight recharge the battery
fields.option_d: immediately end the flight.
fields.explanation:
91.215(c) states that if equipped with an operable transponder, it must be on.  Since the transponder is no longer operable, A probably isn't the best answer.  There are provisions in the same regulation allowing for an aircraft under ATC control to continue working with an inoperative transponder along his route.  

91.215 ATC transponder and altitude reporting equipment and use.

 (c) Transponder-on operation. While in the airspace as specified in paragraph (b) of this section or in all controlled airspace, each person operating an aircraft equipped with an operable ATC transponder maintained in accordance with §91.413 of this part shall operate the transponder, including Mode C equipment if installed, and shall reply on the appropriate code or as assigned by ATC.

In order to keep the battery from draining to zero, thus causing the battery to be replaced, it's probably better to just shut off the transponder for the remainder of the flight.   Option B isn't a good choice, given that the transponder should be turned off from the component, instead of the power switch toggle.  Option C is a better choice -- turn off the transponder from the device, and recharge the battery after the flight.

Keep in mind, though that D looks like a pretty good answer, too, because of §91.7 

§ 91.7   Civil aircraft airworthiness.

(a) No person may operate a civil aircraft unless it is in an airworthy condition.

(b) The pilot in command of a civil aircraft is responsible for determining whether that aircraft is in condition for safe flight. The pilot in command shall discontinue the flight when unairworthy mechanical, electrical, or structural conditions occur.

 

Is a malfunctioning transponder reason enough to cause the aircraft to be unairworthy?  Not really.  The wings keep flying, and the controls keep working, so 91.7 doesn't really apply.

fields.question_text: For the TT21 Mode S Transponder installed in the ASK-21, what is the difference between the "Alt" mode and the "On" mode?
fields.option_a: Each setting carries the same function, but the "Alt" mode uses more power.
fields.option_b: The "Alt" mode has functionalities that were originally designed for airplanes under control of ATC. Use of the"On" mode is all that is necessary for our flying club operations.
fields.option_c: The "Alt" mode will respond will respond to ATC with altitude information, the "On" mode will not.
fields.option_d: The "Alt" mode is a special mode where we activate when we expect to be flying at higher altitudes, or in wave.
fields.explanation:
TT21 Mode S Transponder Manual, page 1 -- 

 OFF Power is removed from the transponder. 
 SBY  The transponder is on, but will not reply to any interrogations
 GND  The transponder will respond to Mode S ground interrogations from surface movement radar.
 ON  The transponder will respond to all interrogations, but altitude reporting is suppressed. 
 ALT  The transponder will respond to all interrogations.

fields.question_text: What is a TFR and how does it apply to you?
fields.option_a: Temporary Flight Routing - The ATC can direct air traffic around a certain area
fields.option_b: Transient Foul Route - Aircraft flying through, but not stopping at an area must follow new routing instructions
fields.option_c: Temporary Flight Restriction - A flight restriction that prohibits flight into an area.
fields.option_d: Transport Flight Route - A flight path reserved for air carriers, transport carriers, and jet liners.
fields.explanation:
The AIM and FAR's both discuss this topic: the former in terms of definition and the latter in terms of requirments. It's a very important type of NOTAM.

AIM 3-5-3  and FAR General Air Traffic Operating Rules 91.137  through  91.144 apply. 

You must be aware of and comply with all active NOTAMS. One of several sources of their existance is Flight Service Weather Briefers, 1800wxbrief.com , and http://tfr.faa.gov/

fields.question_text: What is the maximum pressure altitude allowed without supplemental oxygen while operating a club glider?
fields.option_a: 10,000 feet
fields.option_b: 12,000 feet
fields.option_c: 12,500 feet
fields.option_d: 14,000 feet
fields.explanation:
See SSC Ops Manual  para. 3.11   'Members may not fly Club aircraft above 12,500ft MSL without use of an approved oxygen system, and must have a logbook entry documenting training on the oxygen system to be used, signed by a Skyline Soaring instructor.'

FAR 91.211  - which is less stringent than the Club rule - also applies.

fields.question_text: A pilot goes out with his friends on Friday night and consumes a significant number of beers at a bar, finishing the last drink at midnight. He gets a taxi ride home. At 0800 the next morning, he wakes up with a slight hangover, and recovers after consuming a few aspirin. He notices that it's going to be a great soaring day and goes to the airport for a morning glider flight starting at 1000.
fields.option_a: The pilot may fly so long as his blood alcohol content is less than 0.04% BAC by volume.
fields.option_b: The pilot should not fly for 12-24 hours after the overconsumption.
fields.option_c: If the pilot was drinking hard liquor instead of beer, he would be grounded, but beer is OK.
fields.option_d: The pilot had more than 8 hours from drinking until take-off, so it's OK for him to fly.
fields.explanation:
The pilot probably shouldn't fly for 12-24 hours after the binge drinking. Just because the regulations state that 8 hours is the minimum time permitted between the consumption of alcoholic beverages to piloting an aircraft doesn't mean it's a good idea.  The spectacular soaring weather MUST NOT be a determination for how fit to fly the pilot is. AIM 8-1-1 states the following: 

 2. A consistently high alcohol related fatal aircraft accident rate serves to emphasize that alcohol and flying are a potentially lethal combination. The CFRs prohibit pilots from performing crewmember duties within 8 hours after drinking any alcoholic beverage or while under the influence of alcohol. However, due to the slow destruction of alcohol, a pilot may still be under influence 8 hours after drinking a moderate amount of alcohol. Therefore, an excellent rule is to allow at least 12 to 24 hours between “bottle and throttle,” depending on the amount of alcoholic beverage consumed.

fields.question_text: Situation: Billy-Bob is getting heavier in his later years. His BMI is 35, but still manages to stay under the maximum weight limit of the gliders at the field.  His wife complains of his constant very loud snoring all through the night.  How could this affect his hobby of aviation?
fields.option_a: His flying career will be over, once he exceeds the maximum allowable weight for our gliders
fields.option_b: He will have a hard time finding an instructor to fly with him, while staying under max-gross weight
fields.option_c: He could have sleep-obstructive apnea, causing him to have chronic fatigue
fields.option_d: His weight alone poses a higher possibility of other chronic ailments such as high blood pressure and heart failure
fields.explanation: While all of these possible answers are true, the most alarming part of this example is the very loud snoring.  Recently, the AIM has been updated to reflect the dangers associated with chronic fatigue caused by a sleeping disorder called sleep apnea. AIM 8-1-e-(4) writes about this, and recommends seeing a sleep study specialist to determine if the pilot has this condition.

fields.question_text: Alice flew with us last weekend, and has returned for more flying. With regards to the SSC logsheet program, what is the best way to ensure that the returning introductory members are up to date?
fields.option_a: Check the members website and look up temporary members.
fields.option_b: Launch the logsheet program from the laptop script, while an internet connection is available, which will update data files automatically.
fields.option_c: Manually update the members.txt file in the ssclog\tables directory
fields.option_d: Check the new member papers in the grey bin, and look for new members there
fields.explanation: All of these are valid answers, but the best one is to lauch the logsheet program from the script on the desktop of the club computer, with a good internet connection, this will check the website for the most current data and update if needed.  The members files are kept up to date on the logsheet program, and are overwritten each time you download the logsheet program.  In addition, the prices, gliders, temporary members, full members and delinquent members are kept up to date on the web server, and only when the logsheet program is downloaded from the website will the logsheet program be up to date.

fields.question_text: Sally is the daughter of Frank. Frank is a full member, Sally is a family member.  Sally is a minor and doesn't pay for her flights, instead; Frank pays for her flights. Sally flew 3 instructional flights. How is this recorded in the SSC Logsheet program?
fields.option_a: Make a note regarding this in the text area under "Shutdown -> General Comment"
fields.option_b: Frank should make a memo on the check he writes
fields.option_c: For each flight Sally takes, mark Frank as the alternative payer (on the Flights tab)
fields.option_d: After operations are done, send an email to the treasurer regarding this
fields.explanation: While A, B and D are all marginally correct, the best way to go about this is to make sure that each flight that Sally makes is marked with an alternative payer. Frank should be listed as that alternative payer.  In addition, making a note on the memo section of the check is appreciated by the treasurer.  While there may be some debate as to which one is the best choice, Option "C" gives the best way for us to track who paid for what flights.  If it's written on the memo, the record of the check is lost once the check is cashed.

fields.question_text: Gerald flew his personal glider and landed out in a field somewhere to the West.  How do you mark the landing time in the SSC logsheet?
fields.option_a: Make your best guess for the landing time.
fields.option_b: Mark "Exception" in the "Glider Flights" tab on the logsheet program, set a time. Update later as necessary.
fields.option_c: Make your best guess for the landing time, and follow up later with Gerald.
fields.option_d: Leave the "Landing" time field blank, since he didn't land at our airport, and it's not one of the club's gliders.
fields.explanation: The flight information database is full of missing flight times.  This makes it very hard for us to tally up the times on the gliders at the end of the year.  Please don't try to upload empty times.   The best choice here is to use the "Exception" pulldown in the logsheet program, which has several scenarios: Landed Out, Aborted Takeoff, Simulated PTT, Actual PTT, or Other.   In any event, if you must, please upload a correcting logsheet later, once you get an indication from the pilot when he landed.

fields.question_text: Gerald flew $154.10 worth of flights today.  He owes the club $346.00 for dues.  He writes one check for $500 to cover both costs, with a little left over.  How do you mark this in the Finances section of the logsheet program?
fields.option_a: Enter "$500" in the check field.  Hit the "Add Excess $345.90 to Account" button
fields.option_b: Enter $154 in the check field. Leave the rest blank.
fields.option_c: Enter $500 into the "Account" field.  Leave the rest blank.
fields.option_d: Don't fill anything into the Finances section for Gerald.  Write a note in the memo for the treasurer to check up.
fields.explanation: When any member writes a check for any amount, put that number into the logsheet program, and assign the remaining portion of the funds not used for flights in todays operations into his account.   The Account field is for people who fly on account, not for people who pay extra, and want to have the extra funds put into their account.  Don't force the treasurer to guess what you meant.

fields.question_text: In the finances section of the logsheet, the "Total" field has black text for all of the people who paid, except for Gerald.  His numbers are blue, instead of black. What does this mean?
fields.option_a: The laptop has a bad display, and some of the colors are distorted.  It's actually black.
fields.option_b: Gerald has overpaid. The blue is just to let you know.
fields.option_c: Gerald has underpaid. The red is just to let you know.
fields.option_d: Gerald overpaid, and the duty officer didn't indicate for the excess to go into Gerald's account.
fields.explanation: Whenever the costs for the flight don't match the payments tendered, a color will show up in the "Total" field for the finances page.  Please do not submit a logsheet with any non-black numbers in the Total field!  Red will show up if the amount paid is less than the charges for the flights, blue is when the member overpaid.  In the case of overpayment, please click the button directing the remaining funds to go into the account.  If red, please put the difference in the "Account Field" (dollars and cents).

fields.question_text: Alex is not a member and has a FAST flight.  He arranged the flights, and showed up at the field with the FAST voucher.  How is this recorded in the SSC logsheet program?
fields.option_a: Mark Alex's flight as "FAST" in the flights tab, select "$139.00 FAST Voucher Payment" in the finances tab
fields.option_b: Mark Alex's flight as "Norm" in the flights tab, select "$139.00 FAST Voucher Payment" in the finances tab
fields.option_c: Mark Alex's flight as "Demo" in the flights tab.
fields.option_d: Mark Alex's flight as "FAST" in the flights tab, type in the Check amount that he paid for the FAST voucher
fields.explanation:
If he already paid 139 dollars for the FAST voucher from the SSA, please don't make him write another check!  If a member doesn't write a check, please don't fill it in the "Check Paid" field in the finances tab.  Use the checkbox to indicate that he is using a voucher, and fill in the serial number for the voucher in the next field provided.

(Cost used to be $99, changed by SSA to $139, and we no longer sell the FAST vouchers at the field.)

fields.question_text: Mark is a rated glider pilot and full member of the club.  He went for a fun ride with Bob, a club instructor. Bob was not instructing, but just along for the ride.  How should this be recorded in the logsheet program?
fields.option_a: Enter "Mark" as the pilot, and "Bob" as the passenger
fields.option_b: Enter "Mark" as the pilot, and "Bob" as the instructor
fields.option_c: Enter "Mark" as the pilot, and leave the passenger and instructor fields blank
fields.option_d: Enter "Mark as the pilot, and write "Bob (just a passenger)" in the passenger field.
fields.explanation: Even if the member who is doing the fun flight insists there is going to be no flight instruction on-board, you should at least give the instructor an opportunity to record Mark's just-for-fun leisure flight in the Student Progress Report system, by entering him in as an instructor, instead of as a passenger.

fields.question_text: Sally is an SSEF scholar.  Her first 30 flights are paid for by the SSEF.  Sally had two instructional flights today.  How do you record this in the logsheet program?
fields.option_a: Manually zero out all of the costs to $0.00 for all of Sally's flights in the finance section.
fields.option_b: Record all of Sally's flights as normal, and place all of her finances "on account"
fields.option_c: Record all of Sally's flights with 'free-demo' in the flight type field.
fields.option_d: Sally will pay for the flights up-front, and the SSEF will reimburse her.
fields.explanation: All SSEF recipients have a large check written to the club in their name, to pay for their flights.  As the award recipient flies, their account's value decreases with each flight paid for 'on-account'

fields.question_text: How does one qualify as an Assistant Duty Officer?
fields.option_a: Be appointed by the Chief Duty Officer
fields.option_b: Be a member of the Club for at least 90 days, have a private pilot certificate, and be appointed by the Chief Duty Officer.
fields.option_c: Have a private pilot license, complete the Soaring Safety Foundation's online Wing Runner Course, be a member of the Club for at least six months and be appointed by the Chief Duty Officer
fields.option_d: Complete the Soaring Safety Foundation's online Wing Runner Course, be instructed on-the-job by experienced ADOs and/or DOs, and be appointed by the Chief Duty Officer
fields.explanation:
The requirements for becoming an Assistant Duty Officer are summarized in Operations Manual Section 1.6.10. It's pretty straightforward - show up at the field, be coached by one of the experienced and qualified members on how to help out (e.g., moving aircraft in and out of the hangar and to and from the flightline; launching a glider, generally helping out as needed). You'll also need to be checked out in how to drive the ATV and the Gator. Once you have been approved as an ADO, an icon will be placed on your online "Instruction Record" page that marks you as qualified for this position.

A new member should qualify as an Assistant Duty Officer well within the first 90 days of his membership (although that is flexible, for example, if a member joins late in the season and doesn't have time to get on-the-job training in the first 90 days). And while a Private Pilot certificate is required to be a Duty Officer, it's not for the ADO.

fields.question_text: How does one qualify as a Duty Officer?
fields.option_a: Be a Full (not Probationary) member, hold at least a Private Pilot certificate, meet all the qualifications of the Assistant Duty Officer, and be approved by the Chief Duty Officer.
fields.option_b: Serve as an Assistant Duty Officer for one year and be appointed by the Chief Duty Officer.
fields.option_c: Complete the Soaring Safety Foundation's online Wing Runner course, and pass a test on how to use the Club's computer to manage operations.
fields.option_d: All of the above.
fields.explanation:
The requirements for becoming a Duty Officer are summarized in Operations Manual Section 1.6.9, q.v. Having said THAT, it's also true that it takes considerable on-the-job training to master all the many duties of the Duty Officer (and managing the Club's logsheet program is one of the more challenging ones). Maybe someday we will have a real test for operating the Club's logsheet program (well, there's some questions on THIS program that deal with that!) because it's one of the more challenging things a Duty Officer has to learn.  Once approved by the Chief Duty Officer, an icon will be placed on you online "Instruction Record" page that marks you as qualified for this position.

You DO have to have a private pilot certificate, but also must be a Full member (meaning you've been a Probationary member for at least a year).

fields.question_text: What are the Duty Officer/Assistant Duty Officer hours of duty?
fields.option_b: 9:00 AM - Until operations are over and all equipment secured
fields.option_c: 8:00 AM - Sunset (varies with season)
fields.option_d: One hour after sunrise - one hour before sunset (varies with season)
fields.explanation:
The Operations Manual Section 2.1.1 (q.v.) says arrival at 9:AM until 'everything's done'; however, you should be both aware of variations and flexible because under certain circumstances (e.g., outstanding soaring forecast day, a special operations day) it may be needed to get to the field earlier and/or leave later. Also be aware that the DO (and other crew) should remain 'on duty' until all aircraft are at least accounted for, including members in their private ships who may be on cross-country tasks.

While early starts are nice in the summertime when facing long, hot days, it's a bit much to ask all the time - and it's also not unusual to be putting things away at sunset!

fields.question_text: What GENERAL activities occupy the Duty Officer all day?
fields.option_a: Serves as "Daily Safety Officer", coordinates activities of all other members, manages Club logsheet program for operations, negotiates with FBO, collects money.
fields.option_b: Sets up all equipment for operations, manages ADO activities, establishes launch priorities, notify Potomac Tracon of operational limits for the day.
fields.option_c: Leads daily Safety Briefing before first flights, coordinates use of trainers for instruction with Duty Instructor(s), negotiates runway use with the Fixed Base Operator
fields.option_d: All of the above.
fields.explanation: That's a lot of things to be in charge of, right? You can find these activities spelled out in a little more detail in the Club's Operations Manual Section 2.2 inter alia, and there's a lot there (go back and re-read it!)

fields.question_text: What should the Duty Officer generally do before arriving and after leaving the field?
fields.option_a: BEFORE: Contact Duty Instructor, Assistant Duty Officer, and Duty Towpilot to confirm their participation. AFTER: Write "Operations Report" summarizing the day and email to members@skylinesoaring.org, send email notes regarding any maintenance issues to the appropriate member.
fields.option_b: BEFORE: Contact Potomac Tracon and advise them of limits for operations that day.  AFTER: upload logsheets to the Club's server.
fields.option_c: BEFORE: Check weather forecast to confirm that you will conduct or cancel operations that day. AFTER: Write "Operations Report" summarizing the day and email to members@skylinesoaring.org
fields.option_d: BEFORE: Contact Duty Instructor, Assistant Duty Officer, and Duty Towpilot to confirm their participation. AFTER: Write "Operations Report" summarizing the day and email to members@skylinesoaring.org, and upload logsheet to the Club server.
fields.explanation:
These things can and be done before leaving home for the field and after returning home that evening. They're intended to start the coordination process with the key people you'll be working with that day (ADO, DI, DT), set in motion any repairs that might need to be made to equipment, and let the members know what they missed!

You cannot determine before you leave home what conditions prevail at the field, so you cannot tell Potomac Tracon what to expect! And you SHOULD upload the logsheet BEFORE you leave the field.

With the possible exception of area-wide hurricanes or snow/ice of such severity that members cannot safely leave home, NEVER cancel operations due to weather without actually BEING on the field! The micrometeorology in the valley is very difficult to forecast, and is rarely comparable to what you see east of the mountains.

The logsheet program SHOULD be uploaded BEFORE you leave the field! (Yes, there may well be circumstances in which this isn't possible, in which case you'll have to safe the file to a thumb drive and upload it from home . . but there will be more on this topics later in this training program!)

fields.question_text: Who is responsible for getting equipment set up before operations begin and what equipment is involved?
fields.option_a: The members on the Roster are responsibile for getting the gliders they want to fly out of the hangar and moved to the ramp, the Assistant Duty Officer is responsible for getting tow vehicles out of the hangars and moving the trailer to the correct end of the runway, and the Duty Officer is responsible for setting up the Club computer
fields.option_b: The Duty Officer directs and coordinates with all members present to move all equipment known to be needed for the day from the hangars to the flight line.
fields.option_c: The Duty Officer and Assistant Duty Officer are responsible for moving all equipment from the hangars to the flight line
fields.option_d: The Duty Instructor is responsible for moving the trainers from the hangar to the flight line, the Duty Towpilot is responsible for readying the towplane for flight, and the Assistant Duty Officer is responsible for moving the tow vehicles and trailer to the flight line
fields.explanation:
The Duty Officer can't "do it alone"! 

The precise sequence of equipment movement will vary a bit from day to day, but in general, the DO and ADO should coordinate the actions of all members as they arrive to move gliders, tow vehicles, and the trailer from the hangar to the correct flight line.  On any day of operations, both the Club trainers should be moved from the hangar to the flight line; if it's known at the time that members plan to fly the Sprite, it should also be moved to the flight line; if not, it may remain in the hangar until a member indicates intent to fly it, in which case the DO will assign one more members to retrieve it.

Members who fly the Cirrus are responsible for assembling it.

The Duty Towpilot(s) will take responsibility for moving the towplane(s) from the hangar to the flight line, although in some cases, other members will help move them, under the supervision of the towpilot.

Members who are private owners are responsible for assembling their own gliders (with volunteer help from other members), and the ADO and DO should coordinate the movement of private gliders with Club tow vehicles on the airport. 

Note: Some private owners may push their own gliders from the hangar or use their on vehicles; if the latter, they must coordinate with the DO before driving their vehicles on airport taxiways and ramp and promptly remove the vehicles when the towing is complete.

fields.question_text: What actions should the DO take before commencing flight operations?
fields.option_a: Contact Potomac Tracon, conduct Safety Briefing, set up club computer for operations, get approval for correct operations runway from fixed base operator, identify wingrunners, assure towropes and gliders are inspected, confirm Duty Instructor, Duty Towpilot(s), and Assistant DO are present, confirm VHF radios are functional
fields.option_b: Contact Potomac Tracon, conduct Safety Briefing, set up club computer for operations, identify correct operations runway, identify wingrunners, assure towropes and gliders are inspected, confirm Duty Instructor, Duty Towpilot(s), and Assistant DO are present, hang up flag (if operation from runway 28), confirm all radios are avaialble and functional
fields.option_c: Contact Potomac Tracon, insure that water/beverages are available, conduct Safety Briefing with all members present, set up club computer for operations, identify correct operations runway, identify wingrunners, confirm towropes and gliders are inspected, confirm Duty Instructor, Duty Towpilot(s), and Assistant DO are present, hang up flag (if operation from runway 28), confirm all radios are avaialble and functional
fields.option_d: Contact Potomac Tracon, conduct Safety Briefing, set up club computer for operations, identify correct operations runway, identify wingrunners, assure towropes and gliders are inspected, confirm Duty Instructor, Duty Towpilot(s), and Assistant DO are present, hang up flag (if operation from runway 28), confirm al personal radios are avaialble and functional
fields.explanation:
That's a lot of stuff, right?  You can find more detailed information in the Operations Manual, Section 2.2.1 and the Duty Officer Instructions and Checklist (q.v.).
 
At the beginning of each operating day, the Duty Officer shall notify the Potomac TRACON Supervisor by telephone of the planned start/finish times for glider operations, maximum altitudes expected, and the approximate area of most glider traffic with reference to appropriate local NAVAIDS. (There is some suggested 'patter' you can use on the Club's logsheet program.)

The Duty Officer shall conduct a daily coordination briefing with all members of the duty crew and all available Club members. The Duty Officer will brief the critical information individually to members who arrive after the initial briefing. The Duty Officer will determine the active runway for Skyline operations by coordinating with the airfield manager and the duty tow pilot and duty instructor, will continue to verify that the proper runway is in use, and make appropriate changes in the glider operations as needed. When the glider pattern is changed, he/she should notify all glider pilots of the change, including those who are airborne, via radio. . . . The decision to launch gliders from the currently active end and recover on the other end, versus just ground- towing gliders to the other end for the next launch, is a judgment call left to the Duty Officer after consultation with the airfield manager and the duty tow pilot and duty instructor.

In addition to notifying pilots of changes in the glider pattern, the Duty Officer shall ensure that gliders announce taking the active runway on the radio. Detailed radio operation procedures are included in the Skyline Duty Officer Instructions and Checklist.

Understand that these are the minimum actions to be taken; you will inevitably discover the need for variations due to unique circumstances presented by the day, and your role as coordinator/assignment of the actions of all members present should help you decide exactly how to organize the day for safe and efficient operation.

fields.question_text: What is included in the morning Safety Briefing?
fields.option_a: Introduce fixed base operator (Reggie or Magan), whose responsibility it is to conduct safety briefings at KFRR.  Consult with them to determine what safety-related actions the Club is responsible for.
fields.option_b: Identify duty crew (including augmenting staff like towpilots and/or instructors), weather (including health-related issues such as heat, wind, and cold), operational status of all vehicles, determine who may be flying cross-country, review of signals and emergency procedures, and reminder to pay up before leaving
fields.option_c: Assign the Duty Instructor (alternate: Duty Towpilot) to inform all present of concerns unique to the day that pilots should be aware of
fields.option_d: All of the above.
fields.explanation:
This is all covered in Operations Manual Section 2.2.1:

2.2.1 Coordination & Communication

Before initiating operations, the Duty Officer shall conduct a daily coordination briefing with all members of the duty crew and all available Club members. The Duty Officer will brief the critical information individually to members who arrive after the initial briefing. Minimum required briefing items include the following:

• Identification of the assigned duty crew, and volunteer augmenting towpilots / instructors • Weather, NOTAMS, and facility status for KFRR and logical alternates
• Physiological considerations
• Status of gliders, towplanes, and tow vehicles

• Contact information exchange for any glider pilots flying outside safe no-lift gliding distance, and retrieve considerations • Initial flying line-up
• Review of launch procedures and signals, and critical tow signals
• Emergency actions and Emergency Response Plan

• Responsibility to confirm with Duty Officer the accuracy of logged flight data, and to settle payments

fields.question_text: Ian Fleming has been a member of the club for several years. One April Saturday he shows up to take an instructional flight. When his turn comes, the DO goes to pull Ian’s name down from the drop-down list, but it is not there. What should the DO do?
fields.option_a: Go to the “Members” tab on the field computer and click on the “Full” tab. Unclick all the boxes for initiation fees, SSC dues, and SSA membership, type in Ian’s name in the box then hit “Add Full Member”. Ian is now ready to take his flight.
fields.option_b: Instruct Ian that there is an issue with his current status with the club and to contact the Membership Officer, Treasurer, Safety Officer, or a member of the Board. Ian is free to fly and the DO can log his flight as a guest to the instructor with Ian as the alternate payer.
fields.option_c: Instruct Ian that there is an issue with his current status with the club and to contact the Membership Officer, Treasurer, Safety Officer, or a member of the Board. Ian is not free to fly unless the conflict is resolved.
fields.option_d: The DO may substitute Ian’s name with his (the DO), allowing Ian to fly, and putting Ian as the alternate payer.
fields.explanation: Ian has been placed on the No-Fly list for non-payment of dues and fees, has not satisfied his requirement to attend the Safety Meeting, or because a actions taken by the Board of Directors.

fields.question_text: Tammy Why-not has prearranged with the instructor for a FAST flight. She arrives at the correct time and completes the ground school. When it is her turn to fly she says that the FAST voucher has not arrived, but she has a copy of the invoice she received when she purchased for voucher. What should the DO do?
fields.option_a: Allow Tammy to fly and accept the invoice since the voucher and the invoice both valid forms of payment.
fields.option_b: Allow Tammy to fly and accept the invoice with a promise from Tammy that she will mail the voucher to the SSA.
fields.option_c: Do not allow Tammy to fly, instruct her that the invoice is not valid tender to pay for the flight, and to reschedule her flight with the Membership Officer when the voucher arrives.
fields.option_d: Allow Tammy to fly if she will write a check for $139 to cover the cost of the voucher with the guarantee that the check will be returned as soon as we receive the voucher.
fields.explanation: The only paperwork that SSC can recoup the cost of the glider flight is with the voucher. No voucher – No flight!

fields.question_text: It is March 1st and the first day of normal glider operations for the season. Joe Blow has been delinquent in paying his dues and wants to do so before he flies today. How does the DO complete this action?
fields.option_a: Go to the “Finances” tab in the field computer and select “Fees”. Select Joe’s name from the drop-down box. Type in the prorated amount of his dues, in this case it would be ten (10) months times the monthly rate of $33 or $330. Then select “SSC Prorated Dues” from the Item box.
fields.option_b: Go to the “Finances” tab in the field computer and select “Fees”. Select Joe’s name from the drop-down box. Type in the yearly amount of his dues, in this case it would be twelve (12) months times the monthly rate of $33 or $396. Then select “SSC Prorated Dues” from the Item box.
fields.option_c: Go to the “Finances” tab in the field computer and select “Adjustments”. Select Joe’s name from the drop-down box. Type in the yearly amount of his dues, in this case it would be twelve (12) months times the monthly rate of $33 or $396. Then select “Pay Old Charge” from the Item box.
fields.option_d: Go to the “Finances” tab in the field computer and select “Fees”. Select Joe’s name from the drop-down box. Type in the prorated amount of his dues, in this case it would be ten (10) months times the monthly rate of $33 or $330. Then select “SSC Prorated Dues” from the Item box. In the comment box, enter a statement indicating Joe paid 10 months of dues.
fields.explanation: Prorated dues are only applicable to new members that join the club with Probationary Memberships mid-year. All club members, including Probationary, Full, and Student member are required to pay the full 12-month commitment to dues. The method outlined in answer b) is the correct way to complete the computer input.

fields.question_text: Which statement(s) are true regarding how the Glider Flying Handbooks required wing runners to signal a glider launch?
fields.option_a: Rotate your right arm in a circular motion
fields.option_b: Rotate your left arm in a circular motion
fields.option_c: Watch for glider pilot to wag rudder before rotating arm
fields.option_d: A or B plus C
fields.explanation: This is kind of a no brainer. It doesn’t matter which arm you rotate or in which direction. All the matters is that the tow pilot can easily see and acknowledge the signal and that there's clear coordination between the glider pilot and the wingrunner.

fields.question_text: it is a Saturday and Dakota Johnson (Fifty Shades of Gray) is driving by the club in her limo, spots the gliders, and stops by the club to see what is happening. After about an hour she asks the DO for a ride. What should the DO do?
fields.option_a: The DO should politely tell her that we do not take walk-ons and to contact the Membership Officer to make some arrangements.
fields.option_b: Tell her to contact the Soaring Society of America at http://www.ssa.org/FAST to purchase a FAST package then contact to Membership Officer to schedule her flight.
fields.option_c: Have her complete a Skyline Soaring Club membership form and check the box for an Introductory Membership, a Soaring Society of America Introductory Membership form, and write a check for the SSC membership plus rental and aero tow fees.
fields.option_d: Any of the above
fields.explanation: Although DO’s make want to ignore these and just put her into a glider, that is not an appropriate path forward. Selecting a, b, or c really depends on the circumstances that day and the goals of the walk-up. If it is a very busy day with club members waiting in line for opportunity to fly operation b) is probably to best option. If the person just wants a single glider ride and in no hurry the FAST package should be recommended. Option may be consider if there is time available and the new member is potentially interested in continuing glider flight training.

fields.question_text: Chris, who is not a member of the club, wants to buy a polyester Skyline Soaring Club shirt for his girlfriend. How does the DO complete this transaction?
fields.option_a: Go to the "Finances" tab in the field computer and select "Charges". Select Chris' name from the drop-down box. Type in the $16.00 for the charge. Then select "Clothing Sale" from the Item box. In the comment box
fields.option_b: Go to the "Finances" tab in the field computer and select "Charges". Since Chris is not a member, leave the name drop-down box empty but go to the Alternative Payer box and type in his name. Type in the $16.00 for the charge and select "Clothing Sale" from the Item box. In the comment box, enter a statement indicating Chris purchased a polyester shirt and paid with a check.
fields.option_c: Politely explain to Chris that merchandise can be sold to only club members.
fields.option_d: Go to the "Finances" tab in the field computer and select "Charges". Since Chris is not a member, leave the name drop-down box empty temporarily. Type in the $16.00 for the charge and select "Clothing Sale" from the Item box. In the comment box, enter a statement indicating Chris purchased a polyester shirt and paid with a check. Now go to the “Members” tab and select “Payer”. Type is Chris’ name and hit Add Payer. Now go back to the “Finances” tab, then "Charges" and select the aforementioned input. Find Chris' name that has now been entered in the drop-box.
fields.explanation: As a not-for-profit club, we are not allowed to sell merchandise to those who are not club members.  However, it's not unheard of for a member, perhaps overhearing the conversation or reacting to the needs of one of theri guests, to volunteer to purchase the item and then give it to the non-member . . . leaving no trace of a sale to a non-member on club records.

fields.question_text: In the course of the day Orville Wright is able to satisfy Bob that he can successfully and safely fly the Grob 103 solo. Orville completes a 35-minute glider flight and a safe landing. What can the Duty Office now do?
fields.option_a: Put a nice write-up in the daily operations report calling out Orville as successfully completing his first solo flight.
fields.option_b: In the field computer, go to the "Shutdown" tab and select "Award". Select Orville's name from the drop-down box, select "A Badge" from the award drop-down box, when make a comment regarding what glider was used and any other pertinent information.
fields.option_c: Coordinate with the ground crew to make sure photographs are take of Orville, Bob and the tow pilot.
fields.option_d: Both A. and B, with C optional
fields.explanation: Sometimes the instructor and/or oher crew may want to 'dunk' the new solo with a bucket of water or 'trim their tail' by cutting off the back of their shirt and writing congratulatory comments on it.  While these are traditions, not every new solo may appreciate them! Students who are nearing their first solo should be made aware of the tradition before they show up at the airport with the nicest shirt they own.

fields.question_text: To upload the logsheet at the end of the day you follow the following steps: 1) Save the logsheet and quit the logsheet program, 2) Pull up the SSC website and click on the “Members Only” link, 3) click on the “Logsheets” link, 4) select and click on “UPLOAD/”, and 5) browse to locate the correct file and submit for processing.
fields.option_a: Enter your username and password after step 3)
fields.option_b: Validate the logsheet prior to quitting the logsheet program
fields.option_c: Verify a successful upload by making sure all boxes are green
fields.option_d: All
fields.explanation: The correct answer is d). During step 1) and prior to quitting the logsheet program click on “File” then “Validate Logsheet”. The software will review the inputs and alert you to any errors. After selecting “Logsheets” (step 3) enter your username and password. That will allow you to enter the “UPLOAD/” link. After submitting the file for processing all boxes should be colored green. If not, something is incorrect with the logsheet file and it needs to be corrected. After successful upload, I normally go to the “LOG-SEARCH/” link and verify the fill has indeed been uploaded effectively.

fields.question_text: Kevin has taken a 30 minute FAST flight with an instructor. His flight is shown below as it would on the log. At the end of the day the Duty Officer logs the payment as shown. Is there anything incorrect with either of these views?
fields.option_a: Both the flight and payment logs correct or acceptable
fields.option_b: The flight log is correct but the payment log is not. Why?
fields.option_c: Both the flight and payment logs are incorrect. Why?
fields.option_d: The payment log is correct but the flight log is not. Why?
fields.explanation: The flight log is correct but the payment log is not. The correct answer is b). Payment of a FAST flight can only be made with a FAST voucher. The DO should have clicked the $139 FAST Voucher Payment box and entered the serial number shown on the voucher.

fields.question_text: Eric has prearranged with the instructor for a FAST flight on April 25, 2015. He arrives at the correct time and completes the ground school. Being an excellent Duty Officer, Paul reviews the voucher to make sure everything is in order. The voucher shows an expiration date of April 20, 2015. What should Paul do?
fields.option_a: Allow Eric to fly and accept the voucher as valid since it expires in the same month as the flight.
fields.option_b: Do not allow Eric to fly, instruct him that the voucher has expired and he need to contact the SSA to work out a solution resulting in a valid voucher, and to reschedule his flight with the Membership Officer when the voucher is valid.
fields.option_c: Allow Eric to fly if he will write a check for $139 to cover the cost of the voucher with the guarantee that the check will be returned as soon as the Soaring Society of America honors the voucher.
fields.option_d: Allow Eric to fly. The SSA honors all FAST voucher submitted by affiliated clubs
fields.explanation: The correct answer is b). The only paperwork that SSC can recoup the cost of the glider flight is with the valid voucher. If the expiration date has passed, the voucher is not valid and will likely not be honored by the SSA.

fields.question_text: What responsibilities does the Duty Officer not have?
fields.option_a: Maintaining the flight log, make sure the flight line is moving efficiently, and crowd control
fields.option_b: Welcoming and answering soaring related questions from visitors and assist with completing membership forms.
fields.option_c: Provide the primary radio interface between the ground and flight operations.
fields.option_d: Monitor weather conditions and modify ongoing flight activities accordingly.
fields.explanation: The DO is responsible for safe and efficient glider operations. Anything that distracts from that responsibility is not accountable to the DO and should be handled by the ADO or more preferably another club member. The DO is not responsible for visitors, other than making sure they safety is maintained.

fields.question_text: Full-Member Franco has brought a brand-new motorglider to the field.  He has launched his self-launch motorglider, flew around for several hours, and landed back at Front Royal. How do you log this flight?
fields.option_a: Mark the towplane as "SSC Pawnee", List him as the pilot of the glider, and the glider of the towplane. Add a note at the end of the ops report to have the treasurer and webmaster make any necessary corrections.
fields.option_b: Select "Self-Launch" sailplane in the drop down field for gliders, fill in the pilot's name as the tow pilot as well as the glider pilot.
fields.option_c: Select "Private" or his tail number for the glider. Select "NA - Self Launch" as the tow plane. Select "NA - Self Launch" as the tow pilot
fields.option_d: Since he is not using any club resources, it is not necessary to log this flight at all.
fields.explanation: Now that we have a few motor gliders in the club that are capable of self-launching, we would like to keep usage stats on them, even if they are not using club resources when flying.  We have created a special tow pilot and glider that are presented in the drop down menus that allow you to select self-launch as the tow plane.  A tow charge won't be applied to self-launch gliders.

fields.question_text: On what promises to be a really good soaring day, several private owners show up, all intending to attempt FAI badge cross-country flights.  George Gliderguy announces that he is attempting a 500K diamond distance. He uses this badge attempt to get early into the queue. After launch, he returns only 20 minutes after takeoff. George asks for a priority relight. Where does George go into the launch queue?
fields.option_a: George gets the next tow, since he is attempting an FAI badge flight (reference Ops Manual 2.4)
fields.option_b: George gets the first tow after all the other pilots who are attempting a badge flight have had one launch, but pre-empts other members waiting for a tow in Club ships..
fields.option_c: George gets the first tow according to his arrival time at the airport, as recorded in the launch queue established at the start of the day.
fields.option_d: George gets a tow whenever there is an occasion when the towplane is not otherwise engaged in towing.
fields.explanation: Well, TECHNICALLY, C is the correct answer. Ops Manual Section 2.4 gives George a SINGLE priority for tow, so if he screws it up then he has to fall back on the 'normal' sequencing rules.  However, if there is a towplane sitting idle and there are no other members who have a priority for a launch (e.g., planning for a badge or record flight), then D could well be chosen.  While the Duty Officer has final authority on the tow priority, he is also free to exercise discretionary good judgement.

fields.question_text: John Thomas, a new introductory member, arrives at the field to take his very first glider flight with the club. What should the Duty Officer do next?
fields.option_a: Go to the Duty Officers box in the trailer, locate a membership form, have the new member complete it, and enter the information into the field computer.
fields.option_b: Ask the new member if he has completed a membership form and ask him to complete one if he has not.
fields.option_c: Go to the "Operations" tab of the SSC Logsheet program to see if John's name is listed.
fields.option_d: Log on to the SSC website to verify if John Thomas is shown on the membership list and/or mailing list.
fields.explanation: Membership services will require that FAST or new introductory members complete a Membership form, sign it, and send it back before they arrive at the airport the first time. The information from the form will be uploaded to the membership list on the website. When the Duty Officer starts the field computer at the start of operations the current membership status will be downloaded. When the new member arrives at the airport for his/her initial flight their information is already loaded into the field computer.

fields.question_text: What actions should the DO take at the hangar to setup the Skyline Base Station radio at the beginning of the operating day?
fields.option_a: Disconnect the base station charger from the 110 volt AC outlet, place the charger in the trailer for transport to the operating position, and assemble antenna poles.
fields.option_b: Disconnect the charger from the radio, turn off the charger, and leave it in the hangar and assemble the antenna poles.
fields.option_c: Disconnect the base station charger from the 110 volt AC outlet, place the charger in the trailer, and transport the base station and antennas to the operating position.
fields.option_d: Disconnect the charger from the radio, turn off the charger, and leave it in the hangar, and transport the base station and antennas to the operating position.
fields.explanation: The charger should be disconnected from the radio, turned off and left in the hangar. The red and black cable coming from the back of the radio is not connected to anything during the operating day. The radios are powered by a battery inside the radio case. The antenna poles should be assembled at the operating position, not at the hanger.

fields.question_text: What actions should the DO take at the operating position (runway 10 or runway 28) to setup the Skyline Base Station radio at the beginning of the operating day?
fields.option_a: Remove the bungee cords holding the antenna and mast sections.  Remove the antenna and fold the black antenna elements away from the white center element so they form a 45 degree angle.  Assemble the two antenna poles and place them in the white PVC pipes attached to the trailer.  Make sure the antenna cables are free and have no sharp bends.  Turn on the chrome power switch located on the jack panel and verify that the green light is on and the fan is running.  Set the frequency of one of the radios to 123.3 and the other to 123.0.  Plug the mike into the mike jack for the radio set to 123.0.  Verify the volume setting of each radio by pressing the “test” button and listening to the noise
fields.option_b: Remove the bungee cords holding the antenna and mast sections.  Remove the antenna and fold the black antenna elements away from the white center element so they form a 45 degree angle.  Assemble the two antenna poles and place them in the white PVC pipes attached to the trailer.  Make sure the antenna cables are free and have no sharp bends.  Turn on the chrome power switch located on the jack panel and verify that the green light is on and the fan is running.  Set the frequency of one of the radios to 123.3 and the other to 123.0.  Plug the mike into the mike jack for the radio set to 123.3.  Verify the volume setting of each radio by pressing the “test” button and listening to the noise.
fields.option_c: Remove the bungee cords holding the antenna and mast sections.  Remove the antenna and fold the black antenna elements away from the white center element so they form a 90 degree angle.  Assemble the two antenna poles and place them in the white PVC pipes attached to the trailer.  Make sure the antenna cables are free and have no sharp bends.  Turn on the chrome power switch located on the jack panel and verify that the green light is on and the fan is running.  Set the frequency of one of the radios to 123.3 and the other to 123.0.  Plug the mike into the mike jack for the radio set to 123.3.  Verify the volume setting of each radio by pressing the “test” button and listening to the noise.
fields.option_d: Remove the bungee cords holding the antenna and mast sections.  Remove the antenna and fold the black antenna elements away from the white center element so they form a 90 degree angle.  Assemble the two antenna poles and place them in the white PVC pipes attached to the trailer.  Make sure the antenna cables are free and have no sharp bends.  Turn on the chrome power switch located on the jack panel and verify that the green light is on and the fan is running.  Set the frequency of one of the radios to 123.3 and the other to 123.0.  Plug the mike into the mike jack for the radio set to 123.0.  Verify the volume setting of each radio by pressing the “test” button and listening to the noise.
fields.explanation: The three black antenna elements should be set at a 90 degree angle to the white center element. Setting them at another angle degrades the performance of the antenna. The mic should be plugged into the jack for the radio set to 123.3 MHz which is the frequency assigned by the FCC to the Skyline base station.

fields.question_text: The DO wishes to set Radio 1 to 123.3 MHz. How is this done?
fields.option_a: Tune the standby frequency (red display) of Radio 1 to 123.0 MHz and the active frequency (yellow display) of Radio 1 to 123.3 MHz
fields.option_b: Tune the standby frequency of Radio 1 to 123.3 MHz and the active frequency of Radio 1 to 123.0 MHz.
fields.option_c: Tune the standby frequency of Radio 1 to 123.3 MHz and press the flip/flop button labelled with a double arrow.
fields.option_d: Tune the active frequency of Radio 1 to 123.3 MHz and press the flip/flop button labelled with a double arrow.
fields.explanation: The radio frequency can only be changed by setting the standby (red display) frequency to the desired value and then loading that frequency as the active frequency (yellow display) by pressing the flip/flop button labelled with a double arrow. The active frequency cannot be set directly.

fields.question_text: The DO wishes to contact a glider which is aloft and ask whether any lift has been found. May the DO use the base station to do this?
fields.option_a: The DO may use the base station radio turned to 123.3 MHz to contact the glider and inquire about lift
fields.option_b: The DO may use the base station radio turned to 123.0 MHz to contact the glider and inquire about lift.
fields.option_c: The DO should ask the FBO to use the UNICOM radio tuned to 123.0 MHz to contact the glider and inquire about lift.
fields.option_d: Neither the base station radio nor the UNICOM radio may be used to make an inquiry about lift.
fields.explanation: The base station radio is licensed by the FCC to use the frequency 123.3 MHz for the coordination of soaring activities between gliders, tow aircraft and ground stations. This would include using the radio to discuss lift conditions. The base station is not licensed to use the UNICOM frequency 123.0 MHz and should not transmit on the UNICOM frequency except in an emergency. The FBO should not be asked to use the UNICOM frequency to make inquiries about lift conditions. The UNICOM frequency is reserved for communication related to airport operations, requests for ground transportation, food and lodging, communications with ground vehicles, relaying certain limited information to ATC and communications related to safety of life and property. The base station radio may be used to receive (monitor) any aviation frequency.

fields.question_text: The Soaring operation has ended for the day and trailer has been placed in the hangar. What action should the DO take with regard to the base station radio?
fields.option_a: The radio power switch should be turned off (green light will go out).  The charger should be connected to the red and black wire coming from the back of the cabinet.  The charger should be turned on and placed on the top of the radio cabinet.
fields.option_b: The radio power switch should be turned off (green light will go out).  The charger should be connected to the red and black wire coming from the back of the cabinet.  The charger should be placed in the trailer or on the floor where it cannot fall.
fields.option_c: The radio power switch should be turned off (green light will go out).  The charger should be connected to the red and black wire coming from the back of the cabinet.  The charger should be placed in the trailer or on the floor where it cannot fall. There should be space around the charger to allow for ventilation because the charger runs warm in the normal course of operation.
fields.option_d: The charger should not be connected when the radios are not in use.  The charger is used to charge the radios when they are in operation.
fields.explanation: The charger should not be placed on top of the radio cabinet because of the danger that it could fall and be damaged. The charger runs warm during operation and for this reason there should be space for ventilation around it. The radios are powered by batteries and so the charger is disconnected and left in the hanger during the operating day. The charger is connected to the radios when the trailer is returned to the hanger at the end of the day.

fields.question_text: I you lift the truck bed of the Gator (by pressing the release on the front driver's side corner of the truck bed), you will get this view.  The yellow cap in this picure is for . . . .
fields.option_a: Filling the gas tank
fields.option_b: Filling the transmission fluid
fields.option_c: Filling the engine oil reservoir
fields.option_d: None of the above

fields.question_text: The larger orange knob in this picture of the Gator is . . .
fields.option_a: Gear selection lever
fields.option_b: Parking brake lever
fields.option_c: Four-wheel lockout lever
fields.option_d: Truck bed release lever

You can also see the fuel tank guage, the round white dial just below the parking brake hanlde.

fields.question_text: Wieght and balance calculations should be performed prior to every flight. What is the maximum weight specified in the ASK-21 Flight Manual?
fields.option_a: 792 lbs
fields.option_b: 902 lbs
fields.option_c: 1140 lbs
fields.option_d: 1320 lbs

ASK-21 Flight Manual (9 Mar 83), Section II.6

Empty Weight approx 792 lbs

Max weight of all non-lift producing memebers 902 lbs

Max all weight 1320 lbs

fields.option_a: 154 lbs
fields.option_b: 200 lbs
fields.option_c: 242 lbs
fields.option_d: 286 lbs

ASK-21 Flight Manual (9 Mar 83), page 13, section II.8.
