fields.question_text: Flight performace is adversealy affected by precepitation. What does the ASK-21 Flight Manual recommend for final approach if it is raining?
fields.option_a: The Flight Manual is silent on this matter
fields.option_b: Slip the glider for better inflight visibility
fields.option_c: Add 5 knots to your approach speed as a safety margin
fields.option_d: Reduce your approach speed by 5 knots as a safety margin
fields.explanation:
ASK-21 Flight Manual (9 Mar 83), page 23, Section III.3.

As a safety margin add 5 knots to the approach speed

fields.question_text: It is permissible to launch without a wing runner. If you are departing from an area of high grass or rough ground, what is your immediate action procedure in the event of ground looping?
fields.option_a: Release the tow rope
fields.option_b: Raise the wing
fields.option_c: Lift off sooner to get airborne
fields.option_d: Always use a wing runner in these conditions
fields.explanation:
ASK-21 Flight Manual (9 Mar 83), page 25, Section III.5

Release the tow rope immediately

fields.question_text: You have landed out and are preparing to fly home the following morning. The gliderport you are departing from is unfamiliar with the ASK-21. In your preflight briefing with the tow pilot, after you have visually inspected the tow rope, s/he asks you if there is a maximum speed for your ship on tow. What say you?
fields.option_a: Yes...but it exceeds your tow plane's capabilities
fields.option_b: No..I'm a great pilot on tow so just fly and I can handle whatever you can give me
fields.option_c: Yes...thank you for asking! 97 kts for the launch this morning, please
fields.option_d: Yes...thank you for asking! 75 kts for the launch this morning, please
fields.explanation:
ASK-21 Flight Manual (9 Mar 83), page 32, IV.4

Max tow speed is 97 kts...112 mph

Most favorable tow speed during climb is 50-75 kts...56-87 mph

Lift off occurs at approx 40 kts or 47 mph

fields.question_text: Wilbur Wright used the term "stall" for the first time in 1904 when describing a climbing turn he witnessed Orville perform (the two agreed early on not to fly together so if something happened the other would carry on the work. But I digress). Does the use of airbrakes in the pattern increase or decrease the stall speed of the ASK-21?
fields.option_a: Decreases your stall speed by about 1.6 kts because you are slowing down
fields.option_b: Increases your stall speed by about 1.6 kts
fields.option_c: Neither...stalls don't occur at the lower speeds we fly in the pattern
fields.option_d: The ASK-21 has spoilers so it doesn't matter
fields.explanation:
ASK-21 Flight Manual (9 Mar 83), page 34, IV.8

The airbrakes increase the stalling speed by about 1.5 kts or 3 km/h.

fields.question_text: What are the prohibited aerobatic manuevers in the ASK-21?
fields.option_a: All abrupt aerobatic maneuvers
fields.option_b: Loop forward (outside loop)
fields.option_c: Tail sliding
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation:
ASK-21 Flight Manual (9 Mar 83), page 36

All of the above.

fields.question_text: Is it permissible to fly the ASK-21 solo from the back seat?
fields.option_a: Sure...just make sure you have ballast in the front seat
fields.option_b: Never
fields.option_c: Only if the SSC DO authorizes the flight
fields.option_d: Always
fields.explanation:
ASK-21 Flight Manual (9 Mar 83), page 49

Never fly the glider from the rear seat only.

fields.question_text: The ASK-21 Flight Manual authorizes aerobatic manuevers. Another authoritative source document are the Federal Aviation Regulations (FARs). FAR 91.307 provides the guidance pilots need on performing aerobatics. Is that correct?
fields.option_a: True
fields.option_b: False
fields.option_c: N/A
fields.option_d: N/A
fields.explanation:
False.

FAR Sec 91.307, Parachutes and Parachuting. This FAR describes intentional manuevers that exceed certain parameters, but the intent of this FAR is just about parachutes NOT about aerobatics.

Go to FAR Sec 91.303, Aerobatic Flight, to find definitive guidnace for pilots flying acro.

fields.question_text: The ASK-21 is known world-wide as the best sailplane available for initial flight training through solo to certification and is for fun soaring. It has a fair glide ratio (34-to-1) and a low minimum sink rate that allows the "K-21" to climb in weak thermals. But you can't fly it if you break the canopy. Which are important "Canopy Rules" for handling the K-21?
fields.option_a: Closed and locked at all times
fields.option_b: Close rear canopy first and always close them ground towing
fields.option_c: Never lift a canopy by the plexiglass or the open vent window
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation:
All of the above...plus:

Do not scratch the canopies with rings, watches, belt buckles, cellphones...

When sitting in the glider keep one hand up holding the canopy.

Rear canopy closes first...both latches completly forwards and "clicked"

Canopy hinges are easily damaged in the wind.

fields.question_text: Ground handling is an important aspect of our sport. The wingspan of the ASK-21 is 17 meters/56 feet. This leaves little room with the hangar openings. What are important ground handling techniques to ensure our operation runs smoothly and safely?
fields.option_a: Helpers give a "thumbs up" at each wingtip (better than a verbal)
fields.option_b: Push gently down on the nose to lift the tailwheel--DO NOT SKID the tailwheel sideways
fields.option_c: Never leave the glider with the removable tail wheel dolly attached
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation:
Moving the ASK-21 means we usually push it backwatds by the nose or wing root

Both canopies fully closed

Don't try to turn the glider by the wingtip without having a helper push the nose down

To push the glider forward, leave the canopies closed and push from behind the wing, palms flat on top of the wing, near the spar

fields.question_text: Ground handling is an important aspect of our sport. After you have completed your Before Takeoff Checklist and are marshalled into position on the active runway, it is easy to become distracted. Tow plane, wing runners, radios, tow rope last minute inspection, and making sure the glider is pointed in the right direction. As the PIC, you have the task to retain Situational Awareness on all of this activity and to be directive, as needed, to ensure safe operations. Why is ensuring pre-takeoff runway alignment so important in the ASK-21?
fields.option_a: Because the prevailing winds will shift
fields.option_b: Because with low speeds without rudder and elevator authority, the K-21 will roll wherever it is pointed
fields.option_c: Because the prop wash from the tow plane will affect lift off speed
fields.option_d: Because you are solo the rear canopy may come unlatched
fields.explanation:
At the start of the takeoff roll the glider will go in the direction it is pointed.

The same affect occurs during rollout so landing alignment is equally important. Aim the glider at the center of the landing zone. Try to hold the nose up at touchdown, but it will quickly slow and dip over onto the nosewheel. With only a demonstrated crosswind of 8 kts, the ASK-21 will "weathervane" into the wind (even when on the nosewheel) as the rudder is small. 

Don't relax on rollout. Use the wheelbrake (full aft airbrake) as much as required. Continuious hard braking may overheat the brake pads, reducing effectiveness.

fields.question_text: The ASK-21 is advertised as being reluctant to spin with two people, but you are light and flying solo.  In your thermal today, you try to turn the K-21 with excess rudder to "tighten things up a bit" in gusty conditions, and suddenly the skidding turn becomes an unexpected drop of the inside wing, with extreme yaw into the turn.  You neutalize the stick and apply full rudder opposite the direction of rotation, and before you can really understand what just happened you find the nose pointed steeply down and airspeed increasing rapidly, still with a lot of bank.  What do you do now?
fields.option_a: Continue to hold anti-spin controls - Opposite rudder, neutral aileron, pause, stick slowly forward to neutral
fields.option_b: Recover from the spiral dive - Relax back pressure, roll wings level, then stick smoothly aft until nose is above the horizon, rudders as necessary to keep yaw string close to center
fields.option_c: Increase back pressure on the stick until nose is above the horizon
fields.option_d: Deploy the parachute
fields.explanation:
See ASK-21 POH page 22 section III.2, "Recovery from Spin"

See ASK-21 POH page 33 section IV.6, "Slow Speed Flight, Wing Dropping and Spins"

See GFH chapter 8 page 8-15, "Spiral Dives"

In this scenario, the aircraft has already stopped spinning and airspeed is increasing, so:

a) not appropriate to continue to hold anti-spin controls

b) a spiral dive, or nose-low unusual attitude, needs to be addressed quickly to ge the nose above the horizon without exceeding max allowable speed or g-loading

c) increasing back pressure before levelling the wings may only tighten the spiral, allow airspeed to increase, and eventually exceed allowable g-loading

d) there is no parachute

fields.question_text:
Getting gliders in and out of the hangars is an important responsibility for the Duty Officer to supervise.  The wingspan of the trainers is about 17 meters (56 feet), which is wider than the hangar doors.  To get the K-21 properly into the hangar, you should:

  1. Start by placing the fuselage dolly over the small red painted rectangular symbol on the ramp just outside the hangar - (Figure 1)
  2. Put the tail dolly on AND the fuselage dolly under the glider while outside the hangar (Figure 2)
  3. Have at least two helpers (three is better)
  4. Maneuver into hangar with gliders's right wing first, under the towplane's wing (Figure 3)
  5. Make sure fuselage dolly is on marked square like this: (Figure 4) 
Figure 1 Figure 2
Figure 3 Figure 4
fields.option_a: All of these
fields.option_b: II, III, IV
fields.option_c: II, III, IV, V
fields.option_d: I, II, III, IV
fields.explanation:
Number one is a trick question!  That's actually the mark from which you start putting the GROB into the hangar, by putting the main gear on that rectangle!

Also number five!  That's actually the SPRITE on ITS dolly!  Here's what the K-21 dolly position should look like when properly in the hangar:

fields.question_text:
Getting gliders in and out of the hangars is an important responsibility for the Duty Officer to supervise.  The wingspan of the trainers is about 17 meters (56 feet), which is wider than the hangar doors.  To get the Grob 103 in the hangar properly, you should:

  1. Start by placing the fuselage dolly over the small red painted rectangular symbol on the ramp just outside the hangar - (Figure 1)
  2. The tail dolly can be on or off; if off, maneuvering it in the hangar requires the nose to be pushed down. (Figure 2)
  3. Have at least two helpers (three is better), one on glider's right wing (Figure 3), one on the nose, and one on glider's left wingtip.  Ideally, another one guards the horizontal tail.
  4. Maneuver into hangar by pushing nose so that main gear tracks the dotted red line, aim to put main gear on this mark in hangar: (Figure 4)
  5. Be careful to not hit horizontal tail on sidewall of hangar

 

Figure 1 Figure 2
Figure 3 Figure 4
fields.option_a: All of these
fields.option_b: I, III, IV, V
fields.option_c: II, III, IV, V
fields.option_d: I, III, V
fields.explanation:
No tricks here . . . this is pretty straightforward.  Notice that the guy holding the glider's right wing is actually using his body to insure that the leading edge of the wing cannot be damaged by striking the hangar door frame!

And it's important to make sure the main wheel follows the dotted line precisely - - otherwise, the right wing tip might not clear the back of the hangar, and/or the horizontal tail may strike the side wall.

Oh, and always keep the glider's right wing down, because the left wing has to clear the Sprite!

fields.question_text: The best order for putting aircraft back in the hangar is:
fields.option_a: Grob, K-21, Sprite
fields.option_b: Grob, Sprite, K-21
fields.option_c: Sprite, K-21, Grob
fields.option_d: K-21, Grob, Sprite
fields.explanation:
Actually, the only rather critical sequencing is that the Sprite needs to go in before the Grob - the K-21 can pretty well fit into any sequencing!

Now, getting them out is pretty obvious - - gotta get the Grob out before the Sprite!

fields.question_text: Canopies on gliders should always be closed when the machine is unattended - gusts of wind are obvious hazards for any glider.  One of our gliders, the K-21, is particularly vulnerable to a unique hazard, which is:
fields.option_a: The locking pins can be inadvertently left extended, causing damage when the canopy is closed
fields.option_b: Open rear canopy exposes the instrument panel to damaging sunlight
fields.option_c: Closed canopies allow the buckles on the harness to get too hot
fields.option_d: Open canopies have caused fires in the cockpit
fields.explanation: The rear-seat canopy forms a convex lens whose focal point is right on the rear seat's pilot headrest!  (It can work in reverse, with the front canopy burning the instrument panel in the front seat.) Recently, the headrest was replaced with a non-flammable cloth, but this shouldn't keep you from getting in the habit of closing the canopy any time you walk away from the glider. The burning headrest event does not have to be strong sunlight, as this can happen on an overcast day. Answer B is incorrect because the front seat canopy is possible to get too hot when it's left open. Answer C is annoying, but not something that can cause permanent damage. Very hot belt buckles are one reason why we have silver aluminized canopy covers for both the Grob and the K-21. These can be used to block the sunlight in the cockpit when the glider is going to be sitting on the ramp for any significant waiting period on a sunny day.

fields.question_text:
Billy-Bob just did his first solo in a high performance glider, the Discus CS. While attempting to stop, the glider pitched over and scraped the nose on the ground, causing a big ugly scrape, removing the outer layer of gelcoat.  What are some of the contributing factors that could have caused this? 

  1. Billy-Bob's pilot weight was too high, and he didn't have the appropriate tail ballast
  2. Billy-Bob didn't apply aft-stick during roll-out
  3. Billy-Bob landed too fast
  4. Billy-Bob landed too slow
  5. Billy-Bob forced the landing onto the pavement
  6. Billy-Bob applied the brakes too abruptly
fields.option_a: I, II and III
fields.option_b: I, II and IV
fields.option_c: II, IV and V
fields.option_d: I, II, III, VI
fields.explanation:
Billy-Bob probably has gotten in the habit of landing main-wheel only, and not holding back-stick on the roll-out. This is a terrible habit, and should be roundly discouraged when flying the Discus or other tailwheel gliders.  In order to minimize the chances of nosing-over, hold back-stick during roll-out, land at as low a speed as possible, and gently apply the wheel brakes.  Contributing factors are very heavy pilot weight and forward CG. 

Remember, on roll-out that stick should be full-aft! This is not the SGS 1-36, and there is no nose skid!

fields.question_text:
During take-off, Billy-Bob suddenly kited the Discus CS several feet above the tow plane, once the glider attained flying speed. What are some of the contributing factors that might have caused this? 

  1. Very low pilot weight
  2. Very high pilot weight
  3. Billy-Bob did not get the tail wheel off of the ground during the acceleration phase of the take-off
  4. Billy-Bob was distracted by the Oudie complaining about a PowerFLARM proximity warning and looked away
  5. Low tire pressure
fields.option_a: I, III, and IV
fields.option_b: III, and IV
fields.option_c: II, III, and V
fields.option_d: IV and V
fields.explanation:
1. Very low pilot weight
    1. Low pilot weight could cause the glider to tend to be less nose heavy, and for a given elevator configuration, could cause the glider to get higher faster. Probably not enough to be a significant factor, though. 
  2. Very high pilot weight
    1. For a given elevator configuration, the pilot would need more back stick to get the nose off of the ground. Probably not a contributing factor.
  3. Billy-Bob did not get the tail wheel off of the ground during the acceleration phase of the take-off
    1. This is the biggest gotcha when transitioning to the Discus CS, or other tailwheel-equipped gliders, after training in the ASK-21 and Grob 103. If you do your take-off roll with the tail on the ground for the whole time, you will be unpleasantly surprised. Once the tow plane and glider have accelerated to the appropriate speed, the glider will very suddenly develop lift, and will balloon into the air.  The novice pilot might not notice this until he's several feet off of the ground, and then has to take immediate action, having to dive down into position. Best solution is to plan to get that tail wheel off the ground as soon as practical during your take-off roll. If you have a cross-wind, try to keep the tail on the ground for better directional stability. 
  4. Billy-Bob was distracted by the Oudie complaining about a PowerFLARM proximity warning and looked away
    1. This is fairly common. Sometimes a plane with a transponder can be located nearby, to cause the PowerFLARM to beep when it's not welcome. Be sure to ignore any extraneous inputs while on that take off roll. It doesn't matter if your seat is on fire, you have a tick on your leg, or your PowerFLARM is beeping, keep that eye on the towplane! 
  5. Low tire pressure
    1. I can't believe you selected this.

fields.question_text: During Assembly, Billy-Bob has inserted the left wing and left it on the wing stand. Jimmy-George is holding the right wingtip. Jimmy-George inserts the right wing. The left wing pops out when Jimmy-George pushes in on the wingtip. What is the most obvious rookie mistake to cause this problem?
fields.option_a: Billy-Bob forgot to put the spar-pin half-way in, during assembly
fields.option_b: Billy-Bob put the spar-pin in all the way, during assembly
fields.option_c: Billy-Bob just needs to go to the left wing and push, that's just the way this glider is. The spar pin goes in only after the wings are fully positioned.
fields.option_d: Billy-Bob has the spoilers unlocked, and needs to lock them
fields.explanation:
The Schempp-Hirth gliders Ventus, Discus, Duo Discus, Nimbus and Arcus all have only spar pin. You always assemble the left wing first.  After inserting the left wing, make sure to put the spar pin in only half-way. This keeps the left wing from popping out when Jimmy-George pushes in on the wingtip. The left wing won't pop out because the back panel is shaped in away to prevent the left wing plus spar pin from moving outboard when the wing spar interlocks engage. 

B is wrong because if you put the spar pin in all the way, you won't get the wing more than halfway in. The insertion of the right wing will bang on the fully-inserted spar pin, and you won't make any progress. 

C is the answer that many people think is right. If you have this problem at a contest, the experienced pilots will laugh at you for being such a rookie. Don't be a rookie. 

D could be right if the spoilers were locked. When the spoiler handle is in the lock position, it makes it very difficult to insert the wings. Make sure the spoilers are unlocked and that the water dump valve is closed when attempting to assemble the wings.

fields.question_text: Risks associated with flying the Discus CS in freezing temperatures include:
fields.option_a: Possibility that controls may freeze and bind, especially the airbrakes.
fields.option_b: Possibility that water in ballast tanks could freeze, causing damage and making the glider no longer airworthy.
fields.option_c: Possibility that dump valves could freeze, making it impossible to get rid of ballast.
fields.option_d: All of the above.
fields.explanation:
A. POH section 4.9 discusses flight at freezing temps and suggests use of Vaseline on the mating surface of airbrakes.

B. POH sections 2.7 and 4.7 discuss flight with water ballast, and states ballast must be dumped before going below 36 deg F. Table on page 22c lists standard lapse rate altitudes and surface temps where freezing is likely.

C. Dump valves could freeze first, though not specifically addressed in the POH.

fields.question_text: To lower the landing gear in the Discus CS:
fields.option_a: Unlock the black handle at the right edge of the seat pan, push forward and engage in the front recess.
fields.option_b: Unlock the black handle at the right edge of the seat pan, pull back and engage in the rear recess.
fields.option_c: Push the blue handle on the left side of the cockpit forward and past the over-center lock.
fields.option_d: Push the sliding red knob on the right canopy rail full forward and lock into place.
fields.explanation:
A. POH section 1.2 (6) page 7 describes procedures for lowering gear, but contains a typo corrected by hand. This position is the reverse of the procedure for the Cirrus, by the way.

B. This raises the gear.

C. This locks the airbrakes closed.

D. This unlocks the canopy at the hinge side so it can be jettisoned.

fields.question_text: To adjust the elevator trim on the Discus CS:
fields.option_a: Loosen the green knob on the left at the seat mold to reposition the elevator trim tab, then tighten in place.
fields.option_b: Move the green knob on the left at the seat mold line inwards to release, move to adjust spring tension, release to lock.
fields.option_c: Move the black ball-shaped knob on the right cockpit wall forward or aft to the desired position.
fields.option_d: Move the blue lever on the left hand side of cockpit forward or aft to the desired position.
fields.explanation:
A. There is no trim tab on the elevator.

B. POH section 1.2 (12) page 8 describes the procedure adjusting spring-loaded elevator trim.

C. The black ball on the right cockpit wall is for opening and closing water ballast dump valves.

D. The blue lever is for airbrakes.

fields.question_text: The maximum permitted speed in the Discus CS is:
fields.option_a: 151 knots at sea level, less above 10,000 ft MSL.
fields.option_b: 135 knots at all altitudes.
fields.option_c: 135 knots at sea level, less above 14,000 ft MSL.
fields.option_d: 119 knots at all altitudes.
fields.explanation:
A. 151 knots is Vne for the ASK-21. You must have gotten confused with that. 

B. POH section 2.4 page 19 lists speed limits by altitude.  Plotting these shows the break from 135 knots is at 14,000 ft MSL.

C. POH section 2.4 page 19 lists speed limits by altitude.  Plotting these shows the break from 135 knots is at 14,000 ft MSL.

D. 119 knots is the Vne for the Cirrus. You must have gotten confused with that.

fields.question_text: The yellow triangle on the airspeed indicator of the Discus CS shows:
fields.option_a: 54 knots, best L/D speed without ballast.
fields.option_b: 51 knots, beginning of the green arc (normal operating range).
fields.option_c: 55 knots, recommended approach speed without ballast.
fields.option_d: 62 knots, recommended approach speed at maximum allowable gross weight.
fields.explanation:
A. 54 knots is close to best L/D without ballast, but that is not where the yellow triangle is and is not what the yellow triangle means.

B. 51 knots is 1.1 multiplied by the clean stall speed. It is also the beginning of the green arc, but that is not where they yellow triangle is.

C. 55 knots is a recommended pattern speed in the Skyline Soaring ops manual, but is not related to the yellow triangle.

D. POH page 18 has a table that shows the meaning of airspeed indicator markings, 62 knots is for approach speed at max weight.

fields.question_text: Maximum permitted speed in rough air, and maneuvering speed in the Discus CS are:
fields.option_a: 81 knots for rough air, 97 knots for maneuvering.
fields.option_b: 97 knots for rough air, 108 knots for maneuvering.
fields.option_c: 108 knots indicated airspeed for both.
fields.option_d: 108 knots true airspeed for both.
fields.explanation:
A. 81 knots is max winch speed, 97 knots max aero tow.

B. 97 knots is max aero tow speed.

C. POH section 2.4 page 19 has a table for airspeed limits, 108 knots indicated for both. 

D. Not true airspeed.

fields.question_text: In the Discus CS, manueuvering load limits must not exceed:
fields.option_a: Positive 3.5 G's with the airbrakes open.
fields.option_b: Positive 5.3 G's or negative 2.65 G's at maneuvering speed.
fields.option_c: Positive 4.0 G's or negative 1.5 G's at Vne.
fields.option_d: All of the above.
fields.explanation: POH seciton 2.5 page 20 lists the maneuvering load factor limits, all these apply.

fields.question_text: With a 16-lb paracute, the maximum allowable pilot weight in the Discus CS is:
fields.option_a: 242 pounds (110 kg).
fields.option_b: 226 pounds.
fields.option_c: 226 pounds, unless tail ballast is carried.
fields.option_d: 154 pounds (70 kg).
fields.explanation:
The maximum cockpit weight, including parachute, is 242 lbs (110 kg), per POH section 2.7 page 21.

A. Does not include the weight of the parachute.

B. Is the max allowable pilot weight after subtracting the mandatory parachute.

C. Tail ballast changes CG, but does not allow higher cockpit weight.

D. 154 (70 kg) pounds is the minimum cockpit weight, including parachute (138 pounds plus parachute).

fields.question_text:
Reasons the Discus CS requires a separate checkout at Skyline Soaring for flying with water ballast include the following:

I. Tire pressure required for the main landing gear wheel increases at total weight above 794 pounds.
II. Handling characteristics and speeds to fly change when full ballast is carried, increasing weight by approximately 400 pounds.
III. If ballast tanks are not completely emptied and dried after flight, they can freeze on the ground making the glider no longer airworthy.
IV. SSC cockpit cards are based on flying without ballast, and do not cover flight restrictions or weight and balance with ballast.
V. Flight with water ballast requires careful monitoring of inflight temps to avoid freezing of water in ballast tanks.
VI. Takeoff and landing procedures are different with water ballast.
VII. Internal baffling in the wings can hold water assymetrically, making takeoff difficult if not balanced.
VIII. Water can transfer from one wing to the other making takeoff difficult if not balanced.
IX. Recovery from a spin may be difficult with water ballast, especially if not symmetrical.
X. Filling wing tanks with water under pressure from a hose can damage the wings.
fields.option_a: All of the above except I, VI, and IX.
fields.option_b: All of the above except VIII and X.
fields.option_c: All of the above except VIII.
fields.option_d: All of the above.
fields.explanation:
All of the above restrictions except items IV and VIII are described in the POH.  

IV - The SSC cockpit cards, in the interest of keeping things simple, do not address flight with ballast, so this is still True.

VIII - The wing ballast tanks are not interconnected, though water can move to low side within each tank if one wing is allowed to stay low when partially filled, and will not redistrute immediately due to internal baffles when wings are levelled just before takeoff.  False.

fields.question_text: Flying at or below Manuevering Speed (Va) always protects from an over-G condition for which conditions:
fields.option_a: Elevator and half aileron
fields.option_b: Elevator only with spoilers closed
fields.option_c: Elevator and half rudder
fields.option_d: Elevator only, with spoilers closed or open
fields.explanation:
An aircraft's G-limit is reduced when ailerons are deflected due to extra forces they apply to the wings. Typically the G-limit with full aileron deflection is about 2/3 of the level-flight G-limit. Because Manueuvering Speed is defined as stall speed times the square of the G-limit, aileron deflection reduces Maneuvering Speed. 

Further, and separately, rudder deflection during high G-loading can create twisting forces on the tail boom that exceed the design limit. The combination of a high roll rate with rudder deflection severely reduces the G-limits on gliders.

Further, and separately, spoiler deployment blanks out part of the fattest wing area, which transfers loads farther out on the wing, increasing bending moments.

fields.question_text: Which statement is true for the Slow Roll in an ASK-21:
fields.option_a: It is super easy, just hold full aileron until you're right side up again.
fields.option_b: It is a low-stress maneuver that isn't even real aerobatics.
fields.option_c: It is very challenging and should be learned as two separate half-roll maneuvers.
fields.option_d: The ASK-21 glider just loves to roll inverted.
fields.explanation:
Section 3.5. Slow Roll in the SSC Advanced Flying Guide says:

A full 360-degree Slow Roll is a challenging maneuver in the ASK-21. Being comfortable with this maneuver—and knowing how to do it right—can save you someday if you experience a severe, unexpected inflight upset. While the Slow Roll is used in some manner in all advanced aerobatic maneuvers, it’s an excellent technique for recovering from severe inflight upsets.

It is highly recommended that you initially practice the Slow Roll as two separate maneuvers:

  1. First Half: Roll inverted and hold for a few seconds as you note where the horizon is during inverted flight. You will need this sight picture during the more advanced maneuvers. This also trains your muscle memory to apply forward stick pressure as you pass through inverted to prevent an inverted high-speed situation.
  2. Second Half: After a brief pause, continue in the same direction to roll out of inverted.

fields.question_text:
The maneuvers illustrated in the SSC Advanced Flying Guide must be flown only inside the club's approved aerobatics box.

This box comes with a set of waivers granted to us by the FAA, which were necessary to obtain and to adhere to because:
fields.option_a: We don't want to scare our airport neighbors.
fields.option_b: Aerobatics cannot be performed with 4nm of a Victor airway and one lies directly over us.
fields.option_c: It gives us a nice safe space that no one else is allowed to fly through.
fields.option_d: It has good viewing points for crowds on the ground.
fields.explanation:
Read all of Attachment 1 of the SSC Advanced Flying Guide and the Aerobatics Checklist for detailed depictions of the aerobatic box, the use of which is required by Federal Air Regulations for all of our club's aerobatic flying. 

Our field and flying area lies within 4nm of the centerlines of two Victor airways. We cannot perform aerobatics without a waiver from the FAA, which we have secured.

The top of our box gives us 500 feet of normal VFR separation from IFR traffic using those airways. 

A special mention about fake answer C: Our aerobatics box provides exactly ZERO protection from other aircraft flying through it any time. We do expect that club members will avoid the box when it is in use, but the box is not depicted on any aeronautical chart, and no pilots outside of the SSC will know of its activation. There will be NOTAM and no TFR. 

Constant traffic vigiliance and clearing turns before every maneuver are absolutely MUSTS!

The current SSC aerobatics box is expanded considerably compared to our previous box, which will greatly improve our ability to perform the aerobatic maneuvers properly. fields.option_b: 1574 lbs, 1323 lbs, because the POH specifies 700 daN, and the regulation specifies 2x gross weight
fields.option_c: 1374 lbs, 1374 lbs, because the POH supersedes the regulation in this case.
fields.option_d: 1238 lbs, 1238 lbs, because the limiting factor is the towplane's tost release.
fields.explanation:
The POH specifies 700 daN (1574 lbs) at p. 2.6 (pdf p. 15), ¶ 2.10.

14 CFR § 91.309(a)(3) requires a breaking strength no more than twice the gross weight of the aircraft (2 * 300 kg = 600 kg = 1323 lbs).

A. is incorrect because the POH specifies 700 daN, not 700 lbs.

B. is correct.

C. is incorrect because you are required to comply with both the regulation and the operating limitations in the POH.

D. is incorrect because 1238 lbs is the actual rated rope strength of SSC's polypropylene ropes, and not the limit of the towplane's tost hook.

fields.question_text: In the PW-5, the green arc on the airspeed indicator is from 38 KIAS to 81 KIAS.  38 KIAS is 1.1 times the stall speed for a heavy aircraft.  81 KIAS is:
fields.option_a: The maximum rough air speed
fields.option_b: The maneuvering speed
fields.option_c: Maximum aerotowing speed
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation: Pages 2.2 lists the airspeed limitations and page 2.3 list the airspeed indicator markings.  In this case, Vra (Vno) and Va and Vt are all the same, at 81 KIAS.

fields.question_text: When landing the PW-5, touchdown attitude should be:
fields.option_a: Tail wheel first
fields.option_b: Tail wheel and main gear simultaneously
fields.option_c: Main gear only (slightly tail low)
fields.option_d: Main gear and nose wheel simultaneously
fields.explanation: POH page 4.10 specifies that on landing the touchdown should be only on the main wheel, avoiding tail skid impact.  This is different from the Discus (tail wheel first) or ASK-21 (tail and main roughly at the same time).  Touching down nose first is never a good idea.  Touching down tail first may cause severe tail boom vibration and damage.  Landing with full spoilers may increase the chance of touching down tail first.

fields.question_text: The PW-5 is capable of spinning.  The procedure for recovering from a spin in the PW-5 is:
fields.option_a: Full opposite rudder, ease stick forward until rotation stops, centralize rudder and recover from dive.
fields.option_b: Full opposite rudder, pause, ease stick forward until rotation stop, centralize rudder and recover from dive.
fields.option_c: Ailerons neutral, full opposite rudder, ease stick forward until rotation stops, centralize rudder and recover from dive.
fields.option_d: Full opposite rudder, stick full forward until rotation stops, centralize rudder and recover from dive.
fields.explanation: POH page 3.2 specifies the steps for spin recovery. (A) are the steps for recovery in the Discus, (B) are the steps for recovery in the ASK-21, (C) are the steps explicitly listed for the PW-5.  (D) is probably not a good idea in any glider.  Subtle differences between A, B, C.  In practice, ailerons should always be neutral during recovery for most gliders.

fields.question_text: In the PW-5, the POH-recommended aerotow speed while climbing is:
fields.option_a: 60 KIAS
fields.option_b: 65-70 KIAS
fields.option_c: 50-75 KIAS
fields.option_d: 60 MPH
fields.explanation: POH page 4.9 specifies the recommended aerotow speed of 60 KIAS in a climb (A).  Option (B) may be commonly used by towplanes, but not specified in the POH.  (C) is the recommended range from the ASK-21 POH, and (D) is wrong because the PW-5 airspeeds are specified in KIAS.

fields.question_text: In the PW-5, before takeoff adjust the trim setting to:
fields.option_a: Neutral
fields.option_b: Position 1-2 for light pilots, and up to 5-6 for heavy pilots
fields.option_c: Full forward
fields.option_d: Full aft
fields.explanation: POH page 4.9 specifies setting 1-2 for light pilots and up to 5-6 for heavy pilots.

fields.question_text: In the PW-5, aerotow in the low tow position (including boxing the wake) is not recommended because:
fields.option_a: The glider is unstable in low tow position
fields.option_b: The cable rubs the front of the fuselage
fields.option_c: Sufficient elevator authority is not available
fields.option_d: Boxing the wake is never permitted solo
fields.explanation: POH page 4.9 recommends against flying under the towing airplane downwash because the cable rubs the fuselage.

fields.question_text: In the PW5, there are canopy locking hand grips on both sides.  Which of the following is FALSE?
fields.option_a: Pull back on the canopy grips just until you meet resistance
fields.option_b: Pull back on the canopy grips until the sliding rod by your shoulders no longer shows bare metal
fields.option_c: If the canopy does not align properly, you may need to pull the aft sides of the canopy rail inward by grasping the locking rod, or ask for help from somebody outside
fields.option_d: If the canopy rail goes wide to the outside, it is possible for the handle to be aft but not locked
fields.explanation: The canopy rarely seats completely without help to push or pull the lower aft corners inward.

fields.question_text: The red T-handle at the top of the instrument panel is:
fields.option_a: The tow cable release knob
fields.option_b: The rudder pedal adjust knob
fields.option_c: The canopy jettison knob
fields.option_d: The cabin air vent adjust knob
fields.explanation: POH page 7.2 describes the location of the emergency canopy release.  Without a parachute, there are few cases where you would ever want to touch this.

fields.question_text: In the PW5, the wheel brake is activated by:
fields.option_a: Pulling full aft on the spoiler handle
fields.option_b: Squeezing the brake handle on the lower part of the control stick
fields.option_c: Squeezing the brake handle on the front of the spoiler handle
fields.option_d: Pulling up on the brake lever just behind the trim adjuster
fields.explanation: POH page 7.2 identifies the brake lever.  A is how the ASK-21 works, B is how the Discus works, D is a Blanik feature.  Do NOT land with the brake lever on the spoiler handle already squeezed.

fields.question_text: Refer to the cockpit cards with cockpit loading chart based on the 2 Jan 2022 weight and balance.  You weigh 230 pounds as dressed for your flight, and intend to position the seat back full aft.  Are you legal to fly N505CC?
fields.option_a: Yes, because the allowable cockpit load is 110 kg or 242 pounds.
fields.option_b: Yes, because the CG position would be 52% of allowable aft range.
fields.option_c: No, because the max allowable gross weight of the glider limits pilot weight to 223.5 pounds.
fields.option_d: Yes, because it is permissible to exceed max allowable gross weight if not flown for aerobatics.
fields.explanation:
C is correct, because the most recent empty weight of 437 pounds limits the cockpit load to 223.5 pounds.

A is not correct, because the design cockpit load is still subject to the MAGW limit.

B is not correct, because the allowable CG position is still subject to the MAGW limit.

D is not correct, because there is no concession here for exceeding the MAGL limit.

fields.question_text: Refer to the cockpit cards with cockpit loading chart based on the 2 Jan 2022 weight and balance.  You weigh 145 pounds as dressed for your flight, and intend to position the seat back full forward.  Are you legal to fly this PW5?
fields.option_a: No, because the minimum pilot weight for all gliders is 70 kg or 154 pounds.
fields.option_b: No, because the CG limit would be too far aft.
fields.option_c: Yes, the weight is within the allowable range and the CG would be at 90% of allowable aft range.
fields.option_d: Yes, but only if you sit on a 25 pound shot bag.
fields.explanation:
C is correct, the weight is within cockpit limits (121 to 242 pounds) and the CG is within limits but right at the club-recommended 90% aft range.

A is not correct, for this glider the design cockpit minimum was 55 kg or 121 pounds, with the restriction that if below 60 kg or 132 pounds the seat must be full forward.

B is not correct, the CG is right at the club recommended aft limit at 90%.

D is not correct, a shot bag is not required, but if you did, 25 pounds would move the CG forward to about 74%, which might be more comfortable to handle.

fields.question_text: Section 4.5.7 of the POH says that "looping" aerobatics are approved in the PW-5. Are you excited about flying some loops?
fields.option_a: Yes, but only with a parachute
fields.option_b: Yes, if I can squeeze a CFIG in with me
fields.option_c: No, due to SSC ops manual prohibitions
fields.option_d: No, because I'm scared of loops, but I'll certainly try some if I get brave enough
fields.explanation: Section 3.10 Aerobatics in the SSC Ops manual prohibits aerobatics except when flying dual and even then with all other requirements satisfied.

fields.question_text: The PW-5 seems to like "mean pilots," but has a special note that applies to some "light pilots."
fields.option_a: Even though the PW-5 has no limits on "mean pilots," they should get an attitude adjustment.
fields.option_b: The statement is wrong, there are no special notes about "light pilots"
fields.option_c: A very bright "light pilot" is allowed to fly at night
fields.option_d: A "light pilot" who weighs less than 60kg must set the back-rest at the front limit position
fields.explanation: The PW-5 POH has a CAUTION in Section 6.2 that states: PILOTS OF THE BODY+PARACHUTE WEIGHT BELOW 60KG MUST HAVE THE BACK-REST LOCATED IN LIMIT FRONT POSITION.

fields.question_text: What does the PW-5 POH say about side slips?
fields.option_a: Any airspeed and bank angle are allowable.
fields.option_b: Minimum airspeed is 49 knots and max bank angle of 20 degrees to maintain heading
fields.option_c: Minimum airspeed is 49 knots, any bank angle, and the airspeed indication will always be valid
fields.option_d: Maximum airspeed is 49 knots, but the airspeed indication will not be valid
fields.explanation: Section 4.5.3 FLIGHT says that side slips should be performed at an airspeed of 49 knots or higher and that heading can be maintained at up to 20 degrees of bank. It also says that the airspeed indicator will be invalid.

fields.question_text: The yellow arc on the airspeed indicator is from 81 to 115 knots with a redline at 115 because:
fields.option_a: Those markings show the correct limits.
fields.option_b: Those markings are incorrect because the max limit (Vne) has been increased to 121 knots
fields.option_c: The yellow arc shows the range for performing aerobatics
fields.option_d: The yellow arc and red line can't be wrong!
fields.explanation: 121 kts is the correct Vne after the manufacturer and EASA type certification notices, but the airspeed indicator markings have not been changed.

fields.question_text: In the SSC Advanced Flying Guide, a CAUTION signifies:
fields.option_a: Operating procedures or practices which, if not strictly observed, could result in damage to the aircraft.
fields.option_b: Operating procedures or practices that could result in personal injury or loss of life, or loss of the aircraft if not carefully followed.
fields.option_c: Operating procedures or practices which might make you barf.
fields.option_d: Operating procedures or practices which are very scary to perform.
fields.explanation: See Chapter 1 in the SSC Advanced Flying Guide

fields.question_text: The build-up principle to learning aerobatics means:
fields.option_a: Building excitement for your friends to come to the airport to watch.
fields.option_b: To start out slowly and work on new techniques to build up to performing complete aerobatic maneuvers.
fields.option_c: To build up your courage before each aerobatics flight.
fields.option_d: To never fly aerobatics when there are cloud build-ups in the area.
fields.explanation: See Chapter 5 in the SSC Advanced Flying Guide

fields.question_text: Which is these is true about G-LOC:
fields.option_a: It’s a device on the control stick that can lock out the possibility of exceeding the aircraft’s G limits.
fields.option_b: It’s a loss of consciousness occurring from high g-forces draining blood away from the brain, causing cerebral hypoxia.
fields.option_c: You can minimize it by performing the AGSM.
fields.option_d: Both B and C are correct.
fields.explanation: See Chapter 5 in the SSC Advanced Flying Guide

fields.question_text: Club aerobatics are restricted to the designated Aerobatics Practice Area (APA):
fields.option_a: To ensure separation from all other air traffic.
fields.option_b: To ensure separation from other club glider traffic.
fields.option_c: Because aerobatics in our area violate some FARs, which are waived when we fly inside our activated APA.
fields.option_d: So that club members on the ground can watch and make videos of your aerobatics.
fields.explanation: See 14 CFR 91.303(d) and (e)

fields.question_text: Your tolerance to G loading:
fields.option_a: There's not much you can do.Some people can tolerate G’s, and some can’t.
fields.option_b: Can be enhanced by not working out hard the day before flying aerobatics.
fields.option_c: Can be enhanced by having good carbohydrate stores in your body.
fields.option_d: Both B and C are correct.
fields.explanation: See Chapter 5 in the SSC Advanced Flying Guide, which quotes ad U.S. Air Force Web site for fighter pilots.

fields.question_text: In the SSC Advanced Flying Guide, a NOTE signifies:
fields.option_a: Operating procedures that will wow the crowd at an airshow.
fields.option_b: Operating procedure or a condition that is essential to emphasize.
fields.option_c: Operating procedures that don’t really matter.
fields.option_d: Operating procedures that are especially disorienting.
fields.explanation: See Chapter 1 in the SSC Advanced Flying Guide

fields.question_text: As part of the PW-5 preflight cockpit checks, confirm that the cable end connection is securely fastened at the pull-handle for the:
fields.option_a: Tow hook release
fields.option_b: Rudder pedal adjust
fields.option_c: Emergency canopy jettison
fields.option_d: All of the above
fields.explanation: Although not listed specifically in the POH, loose connections have been found on our PW-5 in the past.  Easy to check.

fields.question_text: The demonstrated crosswind performance of the PW-5 at takeoff and landing is:
fields.option_a: Not specified.
fields.option_b: 12 knots
fields.option_c: 12 meters/second
fields.option_d: 12 mph
fields.explanation: 5.3 of the flight manual states that the demonstrated crosswind performance of the PW-5 at takeoff and landing is 12 knots. It further states that "during the takeoff and landing ground run on two wheels the sailplane is practically non-sensitive to the crosswind action."
